title: foreign aid money spent wisely
story: Having a department specically for “international development” might sound virtuous, but it makes no sense.The Foreign Office, which is in charge of building relationships with foreign countries, is perfectly placed to spend our aid money where it counts. If it had been in charge all along, our whopping aid budget would most likely have been used to fund valuable projects in fast-developing African countries — natural allies for Britain post Brexit.Thanks to the rudderless Department for International Development, it’s been squandered on things like upgrading roads in India — an enormously rich country with a fleet of new warships and a space programme to boot. The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But given this country is facing its worst recession in decades, now is hardly the moment to be sinking taxpayer cash into overseas vanity projects with no possible benefit for Brits. If Boris is determined to stick to David Cameron’s pledge to splash . per cent of GDP on foreign aid, then let’s thank our lucky stars it will now be spent wisely.THREE cheers for Marcus Rashford, a magnicent role model who yesterday won his campaign to make sure Britain’s poorest kids get one square meal a day over the summer. We know it will have been tough for the PM to swallow his pride and U-turn. But it was the right thing to do:  parents struggling to feed their children need all the help they can get right now. And £million — the cost of extending free school meal vouchers during the holidays — is a drop in the ocean when you consider the overall cost of lockdown.We like Rashford’s style, too. How refreshing to see a celebrity using his fame to articulate a powerful argument with such authenticity. NEW unemployment figures make for grim reading. The number of people claiming  jobless benefits more than doubled to hit .million in May — the  highest level since . And because the furlough scheme is masking the true extent of the crisis, we fear the worst is yet to come. Scientists are trained to think about public health  in the narrowest sense. So their instincts tell them to keep Britain in lockdown for as long as possible. But elected politicians know that  poverty and  mass unemployment kill just as surely as the virus. It’s time they showed some leadership and started easing restrictions in earnest. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann cops re test saliva algarve
story: Last week, The Sun reported how a scrap of blue material in the vaults of a Portuguese forensic lab could provide the vital link betweenChristian B and Madeleine McCann.Detectives hope advances in DNA testing may yet provide a full profile for comparison with " href"https:www.thesun news  who-madeleine-mccann-suspect-christian-b-germany " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"the -year-old convicted paedophile and rapist.The material comes from the bedspread draped over the bed " rel"noreferrer noopener"Madeleine was sleeping on when she was abducted from her family’s holiday apartment.Tests uncovered a microscopic a DNA profile initially identied as semen, but later confirmed to be saliva.And according to Sky News today, German authorities are now keen to re-examine a sample from the Praia da Luz holiday apartment where Madeleine vanished from in . Sky News claims Portuguese tests on the sample apparently found no DNA match to Christian B.Authorities in Germany believe their scientists should do their own tests.But Portuguese police may not send the sample due to legal restrictions in sending samples abroad for testing and recent criticism of them from Germany, Sky reports.Asked about todays report about the saliva sample, Braunschweig state prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters, who is leading the Madeleine investigation, said: That information is not mine. I dont know where it comes from. I cant confirm anything.You can help by calling Operation Grange with information on    or email Operation.grange@met.police.ukThe Met Police, who have also been investigating Madeleines disappearance through their missing person inquiry Operation Grange, were unable to comment.Last week, The Sun reported that scientists in Portugal were unable to obtain a full DNA profile at the time but have continued to work on it with new testing techniques.The sample is being held at the National Institute of Legal, Medical and Forensic Science, in Coimbra, near Lisbon.Forensic tests have also been carried out on particles taken from the floor, sofa, walls and skirting board in the McCann’s apartment at the Ocean Village complex.Christian B is currently in jail in the north German town of Kiel after being convicted of drug offences. Last year, he was convicted of a  rape of a -year-old widow, which he is appealing.Yesterday, Christain Bs lawyer Friedrich Fulscher spoke for the first time to say his client denies any involvement in the McCann case. It also emerged that a request by his legal team to the European Court of Justiceon breaches over his  extradition from Italy to Germany was being considered.His lawyers are challenging the evidence and witness statements against him and accuse German authorities of breaching international law.He was arrested for an outstanding drugs offence but then put on trial back in Germany for the rape following his arrest in Milan. The ECJ decision is expected by July .But Mr Wolters said there are doubts over whether Christian B could be released then as he faces another court appearance in the German town of Flensburg over his drug-dealing case, for which he is eligible for parole having served two thirds of his sentence.Mr Wolters told Sun Online: I think this decision [the drug dealing parole] would be the first decision. Andin this case the judge says he has to stay in prison, he will be in prison longer than July .I think that he will not be released in the drug-dealing case, so he has to stay in prison until, I think, January .And so the decision of the European Court is not so important to us. Im not sure that the judge in the drug-dealing case will not release him, its a possibility, but I think the possibility is very small.The second thing is that the European Court must find a mistake in the rape verdict, so only in this caseboth come together he could be released on July .He added we are hopeful, but not sure of being closer to charging Christian B.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jacinda adern troops borders new zealand
story: The women landed in New Zealand on June  but were allowed to leave quarantine six days later when their relative had passed away.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIn a press conference yesterday PM Ardern said that the military would now oversee the quarantine of new arrivals to the country and will audit the quarantine process. Assistant Chief of Defence, Air Commodore Digby Webb, has been appointed to oversee the quarantine operations. He will have the power to bring in military personnel to assist in the operating of the facilitiesneeded.I cannot allow the gains we have all made to be squandered by processes that are not followed, Ardern said on Wednesday. Our borders, and the controls at our borders, must be rigorous. They must be disciplined, and they must have the confidence of ministers and all of you - New Zealanders - who got us here.There is no room for error, evenit is human error. It is totally unacceptable that procedures we were advised were in place, were not.Ardern also said that she would temporarily remove the compassionate exemption which allowed the women to leave their isolation early.New Zealand health officials are now in a race to find the  people who came into contact with the women.Those contacts will include passengers on their flight to New Zealand and other people who quarantined at their Auckland hotel. Despite the two new cases Ardern said that the new infections did not change New Zealand’s Covid-free status. Our definition always assumed there would be cases at the border, she said.The government are still looking for answers as to why the two women were not tested before leaving their isolation in Auckland.It was absolutely nonsensical that the women had not been tested, Ardern said.Todd Muller, the country’s opposition leader, described the failure as “clumsy and totally inappropriate” and asked that the health minister David Clark resign.The women who had travelled from the UK stayed in a managed isolation hotel in Auckland after they arrived in New Zealand.They applied for permission to visit a dying relative in Wellington on June , but the parent died on the evening of June .The women, one in her s and one in her s, travelled from Auckland to Wellington by car on compassionate grounds.Neither of the women were tested before leaving for Wellington but were carrying a supply of face masks.Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield said that as part of their travel plan, the women had no contact with any person or public facilities on their trip.They were tested at a drive-through facility in Wellington under their agreed plan and the results came back today, Bloomfield said. One of the two women was showing mild coronavirus symptoms before being tested, which she initially put down to a pre-existing condition.The other woman is symptom-free.The women remain in -day isolation in Wellington and have delayed the funeral of their loved one until they have recovered.A new case is something we hoped we wouldnt get but is also something we have expected and planned for, Bloomfield said. Thats why we have geared up our contact tracing and testing capability to be able to respond rapidly.We know there are people continuing to come to New Zealand from countries where there is active community spread of COVID-.This is managed through our requirement for two weeks in isolation at the border.On June , New Zealand health officials announced that it was free of coronavirus and lted the strict ten-week lockdown. People were able to resume back to normal le including gathering in normal numbers for weddings and funerals.Sports matches resumed over the weekend which saw people ing to stadiums for the first time in nearly three months.Before the two new cases, New Zealand had reported , infections and  deaths from the disease.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keep your dog socially distanced coronavirus fda
story: The Food and Drug Administration issued new guidance saying pooches should stay at least ft apart from other animals and their owners outdoors.Experts say dogs can catch Covid- from humans, although it is not clearthey can then infect other pets and people.The FDA said the usual ft social distancing rule for people should also apply to pets, and that dogs should be kept on a short lead.The agency says in a public information video:“Though it doesn’t seem like animals can give you the virus, it appears you can give it to them.Soyou’re sick, avoid direct contact with your pets. If possible, have someone  care for them until you’re well again.” The FDA advises limiting contact with your petyou are sick with coronavirus, and washing your hands regularlyyou cant.It adds: “Consider avoiding dog parks and other crowded public places.”Although the FDA says animals cannot apparently infect humans, last week UK government Sage scientists warned people COULD catch coronavirus from pets fur.And last month two people were thought to have caught the disease from mink at a farm in Holland - Europes first potential animal-to-human transmission.Domestic cats have also been infected, as have tigers and lions in Bronx zoo which are believed to have caught it from their keepers.A recent study in Hong Kong examined  dogs and eight cats from households where a person had become sick with Covid- or come in close contact with a confirmed patient.Out of that group, two dogs tested positive for coronavirus, while the cats all came back negative.Most pets that get sick appear to have only mild symptoms and fully recovered.“A small number of pet cats and dogs have been reported to be infected with the virus in several countries, including the United States, says the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.Most of these pets became sick after contact with people with Covid-.”Dr Mike Ryan, executive director of the World Health Organisation’s health emergencies program, said it is “really important we remain respectful and kind” to infected animals.He said: “They’re beings in their own right, and they deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. They’re victims like the rest of us.”The American Veterinary Medical Association says on its website: Based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading Covid- to people is considered to be low.Accordingly, there is no reason to remove pets from homes where Covid- has been identied in members of the household, unless there is risk that the pet itself is not able to be cared for appropriately.In this pandemic emergency, pets and people each need the support of the other and veterinarians are there to support the good health of both.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit wait 12 weeks severe hardship
story: Dr Mandy Cheetham, of Teesside University, has warned people waiting for UC claims are having to choose between heating their homes and putting food on the table. She told the Work and Pensions Select Committee today: A lack of savings pushedinto debt and severe hardship. They were unable to pay their essential bills, rent arrears increased, and people talked with alarm of increased risk of homelessness and eviction.A study done by Dr Cheetham with Northumbria University looked at the experiences of  UC claimants in the North-East of England and  staff working in organisations supporting those people. She said: The five-week wait was rarely five weeks for the claimants we spoke to. For a lot of them, particularly those who were struggling with computer access or digital literacy issues, for about half our sample the wait for a Universal Credit was longer than five weeks. The average wait time for the first payment was around seven-and-a-half weeks, and stretched up to  weeks. For some who had to wait  weeks for their first payments, they were still waiting for full payments even after that. Dr Cheetham told MPs: Some were faced with the very dficult decision between eating and heating - food and fuel poverty was a feature of their accounts. She said one devastating example of this was a diabetic person who had to skip meals because they could not afford to buy food. Some were forced to borrow money off friends and family and many struggled to cope with the shame and stigma of admitting they couldnt make ends meet. The impact on mental and physical health was extreme, people talks about self harm, they talked about anxiety and depression, and six participants said they felt so low they considered suicide. As many as , people in a study of , people who experienced psychological problems as a result of waiting for the first UC payment hit clinical levels of anxiety and depression, the MPs were told. According to new statistics from Office of National Statistics more than . million people have now claimed Universal Credit since the start of the lockdown. The Sun launched the Make Universal Credit Work campaign to slash wait times for first payments so people arent forced to sell their belongings or take out loans to survive - and to make it easier for people to get back to work.Dr Sophie Wickham, a research fellow at the Wellcome Trust, told the Committee that although the main aim of Universal Credit was to get people back into work there was no evidence that benefits helped people move back into the workforce. A spokesperson for the Department for Work and Pensions said Dr Cheethams comments were based on a dated study which features a tiny sample size. They said: They fail to recognise the extraordinary efforts of our staff to help people through the current pandemic.“No one has to wait for money under Universal Credit as urgent payments are available and around % of people are paid in full and on time. In fact, we’ve improved payment timeliness during the current emergency whilst processing more than . million new claims to UC since mid-March.“We recognise this is a dficult time for people on low incomes and we’ve injected more than £.bn into the welfare system – including increasing Universal Credit by up to £, a year - to help those in most need.”One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes five weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the Government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story.Boris Johnson today warned of tough times ahead as ministers faced pressure to increase support for some of the UKs poorest households who have suffered during lockdown.The Prime Minister said the Government had done everything we possibly can to help families in need, and is ready to go further where we can.Research today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and Save the Children suggested around two-thirds of households receiving Universal Credit have been forced into debt during the coronavirus lockdown. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple dream home party bedsit surrey
story: Matt and Hannah Graydon claim they suffered from years of loud partying, drunken sessions and anti-social behaviour from the bedsit next door.The public relations professional couple bought the four-bed semi detached home in rural South Nutfield, Surrey in January .They claimed they were unable to sleep, forced to shield their kids ears from bad language and sometimes unable to use their garden, as tenant after tenant moved in and out of the bedsits.The couple sued their homes former owners Mark and Lisa Crook for £, claiming the sellers had deliberately withheld information about the noise from next door in order to induce a sale.Mr and Mrs Graydon said the couple must have been aware of anti-social behaviour next door and should have told them when they asked about their prospective neighbours.However, Judge Nigel Gerald threw out their case after a two-day trial - leaving them to pick up the bill that is expected to reach five figures. The court heard that before the Graydons bought the home, the adjoining house had been converted so that up to seven rooms were rented inidually as bedsits to tenants.Mr Graydon, , who runs his own PR and communications company, told the judge police attended the bedsit very frequently and they had to put up with the noise of loud partying and people coming and going at all hours.Mrs Graydon, who is a communications director for Caterham School, claimed groups would gather outside the house for drunken sessions - which sometimes ended in violence and police cars or ambulances turning up.She said at times her family felt unsafe using their own back garden because of the type of noise coming from the garden of the next door property.Mr and Mrs Graydon claimed the former owners made adeliberate omission about the neighbouring property.Barrister Kwabena Owusu, representing Mr and Mrs Cook, argued it was a case of having a dferent experience compared to the current owners.He told the judge: Their case is that they werent signicantly disturbed by noise.Mr and Mrs Crook had no such experience .They have been perfectly sincere in the answers they have given the court and gave you at the time.Mr Owusu added that in the  years the couple lived at the property they never had a reason to call the police because of next door.The Graydons accepted that the current occupants are quieter than some of the previous tenants.They claimed damaged for the alleged misrepresentation and said their house was actually worth £, less than what they boughtor.The judge rejected the Graydons claim and he said he was not convinced that Mr and Mrs Crook had the same experience when they lived in the house.The Graydons now face a court bill which is expected to run well into five figures.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris hails australia uk trade talks penguins marmite
story: The PM said the two countries already shared so much and they would thrash out a deal so Brits could get their hands on more Australian speciality foods including Tim Tams and vegemite.In a video posted to Twitter, Mr Johnson brandished a family-size pack of the Australian chocolate biscuits Tim Tams, and asked: How long can the British people be deprived of the opportunity to have Arnotts Tim Tams at a reasonable price He said: Im absolutely thrilled today to be inaugurating the UK-Australia, Australia-UK free trade agreement talks. Its quite extraordinary to think of all the things we trade with each other already even without a free trade deal.We import colossal quantities of absolutely delicious Australian wine, we export all kinds of things including - I was amazed to discover boomerangs made in the UK exported to Australia. The PM said he envisaged a world where Brits send Aussies marmite and penguins in exchange for them sending Vegemite and Tim Tams. He added the deal wasnt all about Australian food and wine, but it would include agreements on financial services and all other sectors of the economy. In a reciprocal twitter video from Aussie PM Scott Morrison, he said he was hopeful a deal could be done as soon as the end of next year. He said: For a large part of our economic history the UK was Australias largest trading partner and the UK remains today one of Australias most important investment partners.As we build back from the impact of COVID- we have a wonderful opportunity to supercharge our economic relationship.It will mean more jobs, more growth, more prosperity in both our countries, and more opportunities for Australians and UK citizens to live and work in each others countries. Australian High Commissioner to the UK George Brandis tweeted that Britain needed to ditch the  per cent tarrf tax on Tim Tams as part of the free trade deal. The PM has pledged to make free trade deals with countries across the world - including Australia and the US - as part of his plan to boost the UK economy after the end of the transition period on December . After stalled trade talks with the EU, Mr Johnson said last week the two parties needed to put a tiger in the tank and forced them to agree an intensied program of negotiations. title: top docs urge pm reopen schools national priority
story: More than , of the UK’s leading paediatricians signed a letter to the Prime Minister demanding immediate action.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTheir letter says the current interruption to schooling is “without precedent” and risks “scarring the le chances of a generation”.Schools for some kids are the “dference between surviving and thriving”, it adds.The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health sent the letter to its members yesterday afternoon and had over  signatories within an hour.They have called on the Government to publish a clear plan for getting pupils back into class as part of a national recovery programme for children.College president Prof Russell Viner, a member of the government’s scientic advisory group Sage, has warned lockdown is doing kids more harm than the virus itself.He said: “The response to this letter in such a short time shows the very real concern paediatricians have for the mental and physical health of children who have now missed many months of education and the broader benefits schools bring.“Children need their schools.“Every child deserves to have an uninterrupted education and teachers, school leaders and local authorities have worked tirelessly to provide that before and during Covid.“But teachers do so much more than teach and schools provide so much more than education.“Schools are vital to the wellbeing of children and young people, providing a range of services from vaccinations to mental health support.“Schools are also where at-risk children are looked out for and supported.“Right now, we don’t know how some of the most vulnerable children in our society are faring because they are outside of the safety net that school provides.  “And, of course, schools are also where our children run around, play and laugh and argue with each other.“They need toto that sort of a healthy normality as soon as possible.”Some years have already ed to school but are subject to strict social distancing measures and limits on class sizes.Other years are due toin September but the National Education Union has warned this will not be possiblerules stay in place.Around .million children in the UK have done almost no schoolwork at home since lockdown began in March, according to researchers.The study by University College London found one in five had done no homeschooling or children have been directly affected by Covid-.“But, indirectly, many children and young people have suffered enormously from the impact that the pandemic has had on their daily lives.“It is our most title: stars call for marcus rashford to be knighted after free school meals victory
story: Rashford, , has been praised for his efforts in convincing the Government to provide £ a week meal vouchers for poor kids in the UK during the summer holidays.After increased pressure from Tory MPs and celebrities, the Government revealed it would fund the scheme after all, despite initially saying it would not carry on over the summer.The Manchester United aces efforts towards keeping the free meals scheme going have prompted calls for him to receive a knighthood.Ex-England cricketer Kevin Pietersen praised the Premier League star on Twitter, calling him “Sir Marcus Rashford” while former Sunderland player Michael Gray tweeted “SIR @MarcusRashford”.Radio presenter Paul Ross added: “I never remember being hungry as a kid but I was a free school dinner kid - as were  of the  of us - and it helped with the Ross household budget. That and the Family Allowance were le savers. Arise Sir M!”The hashtag #SirMarcusRashford was trending on Twitter on Wednesday as fans heaped praise on the young striker.What an inspiration Marcus Rashford is. His campaigning could save lives... Rashford deserves a knighthood, one fan wrote.Personally think you should receive a knighthood. The amount of children you have helped and saved from being hungry throughout the day are in the hundreds of thousands, another supporter posted.If Rashford is knighted it would make him one of the youngest people ever to receive the honour - seven years younger than tennis champion Sir Andy Murray was when he was given a knighthood.He would join other Manchester United legends including managers Sir Matt Busby and Sir Alex Ferguson and player Sir Bobby Charlton. Rashfords odds of receiving a knighthood plummeted after his charity work during the Covid- pandemic, dropping to  .In a statement addressed to all MPs, Rashford thanked them for giving families one less thing to worry about after the u-turn.This was never about me or you, this was never about politics, this was a cry out for help from vulnerable parents all over the country and I simply provided a  for their voices to be heard, he wrote in the statement shared on social media.I stand proud today knowing that we have listened, and we have done what is right.There is still a long way to go but I am thankful to you all that we have given these families just one less thing to worry about tonight.The wellbeing of our children should ALWAYS be a priority.The PMs spokesperson said yesterday that the Government would run a Covid food fund throughout the summer.He said: “The PM welcomed Marcus Rashford’s contribution to the debate around poverty and I said he would be responding as soon as possible.Owing to the coronavirus pandemic, the PM fully understands that children and parents face an entirely unprecedented situation over the summer.To to reflect this, we will be providing a Covid summer food fund.This will provide food vouchers covering the six week holiday period.This was a specic measure to reflect the unique circumstances of the pandemic.The scheme will not continue beyond the summer and those eligible will be those who already qualy for free school meals.”Ministers have said they will continue with plans to put an additional £million of money into local authorities to help those who cant afford basic essentials.The dramatic u-turn followed England star Rashford penning a heartfelt open letter to the government - urging them to reverse their decision.He wrote: “The Government has taken a ‘whatever it takes’ approach to the economy - I’m asking you today to extend that same thinking to protecting all vulnerable children across England.“I encourage you to hear their pleas and find your humanity.”Rashford, who has raised £ million to boost food distribution with the charity FareShare, revealed how he used food banks and received free meals during his childhood in Manchester.The forward wrote: “We relied on breakfast clubs, free school meals, and the kind actions of neighbours and coaches.“Food banks and soup kitchens were not alien to us - I recall very clearly our visits to Northern Moor to collect our Christmas dinners every year.“As a black man from a low-income family in Manchester, I could have been just another statistic.Make the u-turn and make protecting the lives of some of our most vulnerable a top priority.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: germans love brit free majorca quiet holiday resort coronavirus
story: Spain " href"https:www.thesun travel  british-tourists-spain " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"this week started welcoming the Germans as its first foreign holidaymakers since the lockdown began in March.The visitors started arriving in Majorca on Monday as part of a trial scheme to test new coronavirus measures before the more of the country is opened up to visitors from other nations.The trial will see over , Germans visit the island over the next two weeks – while Brits remain on the banned list.And those who have landed so far have said they are loving it.Wolfgang, , who is retired, and Christiane Gmelch, , a bank manager, arrived on Monday from Wurzburg in their first ever trip to the island and are staying in Playa de Palma.He told Sun Online: The security measures are excellent. We know the rules and do exactly the same here.The only thing is its a little bit dficult to talk to other tourists on the next table because of the social distancing.We were expecting many more people, but its nice for us, there are so few.Baibel and Matthias Drews who have been going to Majorca for the past  years arrived from Emsdetten on Monday for a weeks holiday in Playa de Palma.Baibel, a civil servant, said: The staff in the hotel take your temperature when you arrive, then at breakfast and again in the evening.If you go out of the hotel they will also take it again. When we came before there were many more people on the beach, but not so many now.“Supposedly, more cafes and bars are meant to open up tomorrow. title: chicken factory wales kfc
story: At least one staff member at the  Sisters Food Group site in Anglesey, North Wales is being treated in hospital and  others have tested positive.The plant processes chicken for fast food chain KFC and other major retailers.Paddy McNaught, regional officer for Unite the Union, described it as a major outbreak after a quarter of the plants  workers are self-isolating.He added: The company are taking this seriously.Our stewards are working with the company on site to put protective measures in place.But theres no doubt that people are very frightened. Theyre concerned about bringing the virus home to vulnerable members of their families, and theyre concerned about creating a spike in cases on the island.The  Sisters Food Group is one of the largest food producers in the UK, with sites across the UK and brands including Foxs Biscuits and Hollands Pies.It also produces about a third of all the poultry products consumed each day in the country and has more than , workers in its specialist factories.A spokesman told the BBC: We have had a series of measures in place for some time including regular and intensive deep cleaning and disinfecting regimes, the wearing of protective visors in production areas and implementing social distancing throughout the factory.In a statement the company said it was working to provide the safest possible working environment at the site in Llangefni, Anglesey.It added: As a company policy we will confirm cases, but will not provide running commentaries nor disclose employee data.A spokesman for Anglesey council said: The North Wales Regional Test, Trace, Protect team is responding to the cluster of coronavirus cases at the Two Sisters plant in Llangefni as a priority, and supporting the workplace.Key agencies including Public Health Wales, Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, Health and Safety Executive and both Anglesey and Gwynedd Councils are working together to support and advise the employer and those employees who have tested positive, together with their contacts.The Sun Online contacted KFC for a comment. title: chinese wet markets roasted dog meat yulin festival companion status
story: Beijing last month said it was banning canine meat from the dinner table after removing dogs from its official list of food for human consumption and giving them companion status. China is responsible for killing million dogs for human consumption each year.Traders at " rel"noreferrer noopener"wet markets flog canned meat, dog sausages, roasted legs — and even dog penises.Beijing last month signalled that it could ban canine meat after removing dogs from its official list of livestock. But despite giving dogs companion status,  Beijing is yet to ban the eating them.Because of this thousands of dogs have been slaughtered, butchered, cooked and eaten for the ten-day Lychee and Dog Meat Festival which kicks off this Sunday. Footage from last year’s event, which showed a dog being blowtorched alive, caused outrage around the world.Ahead of the festival, animal rights campaigners secretly filmed a specialised dog meat market on the outskirts of Yulin.During the visit they rescued  puppies alive from another market — from one of many in the city.One of the rescuers, Jener Chen, said: I cant believe that anyone would even want to eat these adorable little darlings.My follow the central governments message about dogs being pets and stop the trade.She said: Like the Chinese government said, these puppies are companions not livestock, and cities like Yulin should put title: cecil rhodes statue oxford oriel college down black lives matter
story: The famous college made the recommendation after an outcry over his links with Britain’s colonial past by Black Lives Matter protesters.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterThe Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group had called for the image of the controversial mining magnate and empire builder to be removed from Oriel College, arguing the university has failed to address its institutional racism.Hundreds of protesters had gathered in front of the Rhodes statue on the High Street in Oxford recently as part of the Black Lives Matter movement.Carole Souter, the current master of St Cross College and former chief executive of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, will chair an independent commission into the issue.Announcing it was launching an independent public inquiry into the key issues surrounding the statue, a statement by the College said: “The Governing Body of Oriel College has today voted to launch an independent Commission of Inquiry into the key issues surrounding the Rhodes statue.“They also expressed their wish to remove the statue of Cecil Rhodes and the King Edward Street Plaque.This is what they intend to convey to the Independent Commission of Inquiry.Rhodes was one of the era most famous imperialists, with Rhodesia - now Zimbabwe and Zambia - named after him.  Born in Bishops Stortford in , he was a sickly child beforeheading to Africa aged .He grew cotton before moving into diamond mining, founding the De Beers firm.As Prime Minister of the Cape Colony from  to , his government restricted the rights of black Africans by setting financial qualications for voting.He attended Oriel College in . On his death in  the Rhodes Scholarship was set up to help non-British students study at Oxford. Rhodes Scholars include Bill Clinton and three former Australian PMs.Students campaigned to have the figure of Victorian empire builder torn down in  over claims he was a racist. But Oriel College decided to keep it following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding. “Both of these decisions were reached after a thoughtful period of debate and reflection, and with the full awareness of the impact these decisions are likely to have in Britain and around the world.The commission will deal with the issue of the Rhodes legacy and how to improve access and attendance of BAME undergraduate, graduate students and faculty, together with a review of how the colleges st-century commitment to ersity can sit more easily with its past.An open letter from campaigners to the universitys vice-chancellor claimed the institution has only made inconsequential inroads into tackling the material legacy of imperialism, adding it is not enough.Thousands of people signed two petitions calling for the statue of colonialist Rhodes at Oriel College to be taken down.A student at Oriel in his youth, Rhodes left the college money and also endowed the Rhodes Scholarships, which have allowed more than , students from countries around the world, including former US President Bill Clinton, to study at Oxford.The mining magnate was a central figure in Britains colonial project in southern Africa, giving his name to Rhodesia, present-day Zimbabwe, and founding the De Beers diamond empire.It comes amid a wider decolonise movement sweeping universities across the world in recent years.The Rhodes Must Fall movement was established in  at Cape Town University, and later spread to Oxford, where students demanded the statue of Rhodes was removed from Oriel College.In , Oriel College decided to keep the statue following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding.Elsewhere today work started in central London to remove the metal boards covering Sir Winston Churchills statue ahead of the French presidents visit to London tomorrow.Sir Winstons statue, along with those of Nelson Mandela and Gandhi, was boarded up on June , after it was defaced with graffiti saying he was a racist during a Black Lives Matter demonstration.The news comes after a statue of th century slave trader Edward Colston was pulled down and dumped into Bristol Harbour during a recent Black Lives Matter protest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle harry archewell trademark application rejected
story: The former royals, who have reportedly delayed the launch of their organization after relocating to LA amid the pandemic, have hit a stumbling block with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, after submitting their application on March .Paperwork seen by The Sun shows it was filed by Cobblestone Lane LLC, which is registered in Delaware but linked to the Beverly Hills offices of a Hollywood power lawyer, who has worked for Meghan for years.As reported, Meghan and Harry are looking into creating a non-profit organization which offers emotional support groups, a multimedia educational empire, and a well-being website, similar to the former actresss deleted blog, The Tig.An examiner was assigned to review their application on May  and they have since been sent an Irregularity Notice by the USPTO addressing a catalog of errors, including the vague nature of the proposed charitable work, according to documents.The Notice features a number of changes which need to be made by the couples attorney, Marjorie Witter Norman, by August  - otherwise the application will become abandoned.  The International Bureau considers the list of goods and or services listed for the non-profit as being too vague for the purposes of classication.The Notice reads: The wording providing a website featuring content relating to philanthropy, monetary giving, volunteer and career opportunities in International Class  is also indefinite and over broad, and must be claried to specy the nature of the content provided.The Notice also states that Meghan and Harry need to pay some additional fees to process their application.A Non-Final Action was sent on June , and their trademark can be held without being active until the required amendments are filed.In a final blunder, the examiner claims in the Non-Final Office Action: The application was unsigned, resulting in the application not being properly veried.The Sun understands even the most diligently drafted trademark application may be initially rejected by the USPTO, with one in five failing their first examination.Meghan and Harry, who are currently holed up at Tyler Perrys million LA mansion, confirmed plans for their charity in April and said they look forward to getting back to work after stepping down from royal le in January and ditching their Sussex Royal brand. We connected to this concept for the charitable organization we hoped to build one day, and it became the inspiration for our sons name, they told The Daily . To do something of meaning, to do something that matters. Archewell is a name that combines an ancient word for strength and action, and another that evokes the deep resources we each must draw upon.They added: We look forward to launching Archewell when the time is right.The non-profit aims to offer classes, lectures, seminars, conferences, workshops, and retreats on a iety of topics, run a mentoring scheme, or conduct and host events and exhibitions for cultural, sporting, health, mental health and entertainment purposes, as well as the potential to self-publish articles, magazines, books, music, podcasts, television shows, and computer software.According to reports this week, they have delayed their plans until at least next year, as they focus their efforts on the Black Lives Matter movement and fighting COVID-. Describing how a public launch is now off the cards, a source told the Daily : Whats absolutely clear is that they want to get it right and theres no point in rushing.They are settling into a new le, a new era. This is about getting it right and making sure they are able to make the dference they want to make.The Sun has reached out to Meghan and Harrys rep and trademark attorney for comment. Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook TheSunUS and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSunUS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. It comes as the government comes under increasing scrutiny over the controversial Westferry Printworks planning application. The Prime Minister told MPs that he certainly had no correspondence about the matter and that Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick would respond to any concernsthere is anything to be said. But asked three times what contact the Prime Minister has had with Mr Desmond, a Downing Street source would only say: No-one in Number  has discussed the application with Mr Desmond. On Monday, Mr Jenrick defended his decision to approve a controversial planning application by Mr Desmond, a Conservative party donor. He told MPs he had acted in good faith and within the rules in backing Richard Desmondaposs scheme to create , homes in east London. Mr Jenrick added that relevant documents had been handed to the top official in No . Thereaposs no suggestion of any wrongdoing on the part of Mr Desmond.But Labour called for an inquiry to clear up the bad smell over the decision.The politan Police said they would not be taking any action.During PMQs on Wednesday, Mr Johnson was pressed on the issue once more.Labour MP Christian Mathesonsaid: The Prime Minister has previously stated to the House that he had no correspondence or discussions withabout the Westferry Printworks application. Will he now also confirm that none of his officials or advisers also had such correspondence or discussions withor his officials and advisers and will the Prime Minister undertake to publish all correspondence relating to this matter whenreports  Mr Johnson responded: I certainly had no correspondence about this matter myself and nor, as far as Iaposm aware, did any of my officials, butthere is anything to be said I know that, I think,has written toand he will be writing back. Mr Jenrick approved the application, which was previously rejected by Tower Hamlets Council, the day before the introduction of a new council community levy which would have resulted in the company paying an additional £ million. He has also come under criticism after it emerged Mr Desmond raised the issue with him at a Conservative fundraising dinner in November and, two weeks after planning permission was granted, donated £, to the Tories.

story: NewsFocus on Brexit trade talks with EU not Brunei, Labour urges Liz TrussShadow International Trade Secretary Emily Thornberry said Brussels should be the Governments main focusShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUN NewsThe UK and EU are locked in talks to strike a trade deal " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters were urged to focus on striking a Brexit trade deal with Brussels rather than hunting for pacts with small countries today. International Trade Secretary Liz Truss revealed the UK wanted to become a member of the -strong Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacic Partnership. Countries signed-up to the pact include Australia and New Zealand – which the UK will open separate talks in the coming weeks – as well as Brunei, Vietnam and Peru. Ms Truss told the Commons: Agreements with New Zealand and Australia are an important step towards our vision of a truly global Britain – a Britain that is once again a fierce campaigner for free trade.  A Britain that leads by example and membership of CPTPP is the next logical step. “Joining the agreement would show the rest of the world we are back as a proud, independent nation prepared to look far beyond our own shores.Her Labour counterpart Emily Thornberry said trade deal talks were already underway with CPTPP countries apart from “Malaysia and Brunei, which between them accounted for just .% of the UKaposs total world trade last year”.Urging the Government to target efforts on securing a deal with the EU, she added: “The businesses I speak to around the country simply cannot understand why the Government is spending so much time and effort trying to negotiate international trade deals of relatively little value when it is yet to secure our continued trade with Europe.  “When the % of our trade that depends on Europe is still hanging in the balance then that is where the Governmentaposs priorities should lie.” While Britain formally left the bloc on January , exit triggered an -month transition to allow time to agree a trade pact. The clock is ticking down to the December  deadline when, the Government insists, the transition will end and not be extended. However, talks have stalled over allowing EU boats to fish in British waters and the UK having access to the single market. Sue Davies, head of consumer protection and food policy at consumer group Which , said: There are many potential benefits to be gained from trade deals with Australia and New Zealand. “Ultimately, their success will be judged by the impact they have on the price, choice and safety of products and services we use everyday so any deals must reflect consumersapos expectations.

title: give schools resources need reopen
story: NewsFour vital demands Boris Johnson must meet so our children can go back to schoolEXCLUSIVE: Experts, including those at Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, have called on Boris Johnson to fund and provide the resources to get kids back to schoolShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA Year  pupil doing her work - but when will schools be able to fully reopen  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Daily Mirror today demands Boris Johnson takes urgent action to get all our children back in school. Thousands of youngsters, particularly those from disadvantaged families, face a ruined educationthey are not able tosafely in September.We urge the PM to find alternative class space, fund extra teachers, give poor kids free internet and help those who have fallen behind. Lib Dem Layla Moran said: “Schools need more resources. Mr Johnson needs to take responsibility for this shambles.” As millions of children face six months out of class, medical and educational chiefs are also urging the PM to give schools the resources they need to reopen this autumn. Union leaders, medical and education chiefs, backed by the Mirror’s campaign, are warning that the poorest and most vulnerable children will struggle to close the attainment gap. Prof Russell Viner, of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said top doctors have a “very real concern” for children’s health. More than , paediatricians have also signed an unprecedented open letter to the PM, calling for a clear plan for getting children back to school. Teachers’ leaders warned yesterday that England’s schools would not be able to fully reopen after the summer holidays under current distancing rules requiring just  pupils in a class. Today, the Mirror is calling for the Government to work with parents, teachers, education unions and council leaders to get children back into school. We want ministers to to find alternative spaces, such as church halls, community centres, sports venues and libraries to give schools the space they need to maintain social distancing. Heads should be given funding to hire extra staff, including supply and trainee teachers and –it’s safe for them – recently retired teachers. The poorest children should be given free internet and equipment to narrow the ide, so no child is left behind.  And we need a massive catch-up programme to run over the over the summer, and beyond, to help those who have missed out on education at home. Prof Viner said: “Children need their schools. Every child deserves to have an uninterrupted education. But teachers do so much more than teach and schools provide so much more than education. Schools are vital to the wellbeing of children, providing a range of services from vaccinations to mental health support. Schools are also where at-risk children are looked out for and supported. Schools are also where our children run around, play and laugh and argue with each other. They need toto that sort of a healthy normality as soon as possible.”  Lib Dem’s education spokeswoman, Layla Moran, said: “Making our High Streets Covid-secure is critical. But it seems the Prime Minister is more concerned about allowing betting shops to re-open than getting children safely back into school. “It shows where the Government’s priorities lie. Schools urgently need the resources for more space and staff so that more pupils cansafely. Boris Johnson needs to take responsibility for this shambles, work with teachers and experts to agree a plan and stop treating our schools like a political football.” Labour Leader Keir Starmer told the Mirror: “It was Education Secretary Gavin Williamson who said on June  we’re not able to welcome all primary children back for a full month before the summer. I have said repeatedly that I want schools to reopen as soon as possible. I’ve offered to work with the Prime Minister to address this issue.” Coronavirusandschools.org.uk is giving parents and carers educational advice from real teachers while the schools are closed. The website has been set up by the National Education Union who represent almost half a million teachers and support staff. It features video tips from teachers, QAs on exams and tests, learning at home and child wellbeing. Plus there are fun activities parents can do with their children to stimulate their brains and keep them learning.  Click here to check it out for advice, resources and useful links. Mr Starmer, who has sent his own children to school through the lockdown because his we works for the NHS, added: “This is a Government with a majority of , it has its responsibilities and it should be doing everything in its power to reopen schools as soon as possible. The PM wants all England’s children back in school from September, after six months of coronavirus disruption. But he has tried to sht the blame for the fact that many of those in the years that are eligible tohave not yet done so.  Government plans to bring in Years R,  and  are in chaos, and a third of England’s primary failed to do so by June . Proposals to bring back Years , ,  and  by the start of July had to be dropped after officials accepted there was not enough space to maintain social distancing. Distancing rules have left schools scrambling to find space and rope in support staff to lead lessons. Ministers have been urged to adopt more creative proposals, including taking a Nightingale approach – based on the temporary hospitals set up to treat Covid- patients – to schools by providing extra space in community centres and town halls.  They have also been told to make sure heads have enough funding to encourage recently retired and supply teachers back into the classroomit is safe for them to do so. Downing Street is planning to set out its “catch up” plans for the summer later this week, and further plans “within weeks” to get more children back into the classroom after the summer holidays. The PM’s official spokesman said: “The PM has set out a very clear message… school is safe and he wants parents to send their children back to school. We’ll continue to encourage parents to have their kids back in school and I’m sure those numbers will continue to rise.” But Mr Johnson suggested that Labour and the trade unions were hampering efforts to reopen. He said: “The kids that can go to school, should go to school and wouldn’t it be a fine thingwe heard from all sides of the House that schools are safe to go to, rather than the wibble-wobble that we’ve heard from the Opposition ” But four education unions being quizzed by the Commons Education committee hit back, and demanded more clarity and action from the Government.  Mary Bousted, joint general secretary of the National Education Union, warned MPs something would have to givethe Government wanted schools to open fully in September under current rules. “If the Government retains its social distancing rules, then they can’t [opne],” she said. “So that’s why we then need to look at an education recovery plan, which is focused on more than school buildings. “[It’s] about increasing the physical footprint of the school, about increasing the numbers of teachers available to teach smaller classes, and about a national plan for blended learning.” Jon Richards, National Secretary at Unison, said “you have to have facilities set up” and there were still “serious issues” around cleaning and canteens. Julie McCulloch, of the ASCL union, said: “If it’s at all possible and considered safe then absolutely we want all children to be back in school from September. “That is by far the best solution. But we’re not able to do that at the moment within the Government’s own protective measures guidance. The maths just doesn’t work.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGym bunnies and the footy-mad may be jumping for joy tonight as the Culture Secretary confirmed the Government hoped to reopen local facilities by the start next month.At todayaposs Downing Street daily coronavirus briefing, Oliver Dowden gave footy fans the news they had all been waiting for when he suggested Premier League supporters could be back inside stadiums as soon as September.But he also hinted that gyms and leisure centres could be back as soon as July , while five-a-side football could also be allowed by that time, too, as grassroot sports form part of the focus of the next stage of the staged easing of the lockdown. Premier League football ed tonight, but in empty stadiums. Dowden said: Sports recovery is never just about elite sports. I know people are itching to get back to their gyms, their leisure centres, their five-a-side leagues… and all the normal fitness activities. People will be asked to avoid swimming butterfly at busy times or overtaking other pool users in order to maintain social distancing in the water, according to new guidance released today.  Swim England is also recommending arriving with a swimming costume under clothes and showering at home to reduce the amount of time spent in changing rooms when facilities are allowed to welcome visitors again. Pools are being encouraged to only offer sessions that can be booked in advance and apply one-way systems on poolside to help keep swimmers apart. Facilities were forced to close in March alongside gyms and other public spaces as the Government established strict measures to try and slow the spread of coronavirus. Chief executive of Swim England Jane Nickerson said: When pools reopen it will not be a case of business as usual and we know that things will have to be dferent. title: owning prime minister ultimate status
story: NewsopinionOwning a Prime Minister is the ultimate status symbol for a footballer. Especiallyits Boris JohnsonMarcus Rashford, -year-old son of a single mum, ran rings around a -year-old, Eton-educated man of wealth and power. Whats the point of Boris Johnson, again ShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUN Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPerhaps Boris Johnson will be wrapped in chrome vinyl, and de-badged. He might be painted gold, dipped in glitter and placed in a black marbled atrium.A Premier League footballer has never owned a Prime Minister before. Having done more than any number of high-end family lawyers to make Johnson cough up for the children of single parents, Marcus Rashford may be wondering what to do with the increasingly-whfy carcass of the PMaposs career. It is the likes of Johnson - that is to say, fact-free throb-jockeys - who have established the cliche of footballers wasting their wealth on blingtastic tat. Far more went on properties, or charity, or rehab. In Rashfordaposs case, he built his mum and siblings an unassumingly-neat house a few miles from where they grew up, and moved in with them. He was renting his family a place to live at the age of , paying his taxes, and thanking his lucky stars. When Johnson was , he spent a gap year teaching Latin to Australians, the benefits of which, beyond making jokes that have to be Googled, no-one has yet fathomed. Inutilus, ergo sum. In the years immediately preceding Rashfordaposs birth, Johnson wrote that poorer, working mums create adverse consequences for family le and society as a whole - in that unloved and undisciplined children are more likely to become hoodies, NEETS, and mug you on the street corner. Heaposs mugged you all right, sunshine. Mugged you RIGHT off. Johnson once said it was outrageous that married couples should pay for single mothersapos desire to procreate independently of men. And yesterday he announced every taxpayer in the land - which includes single parents as well as married ones, by the by - will be contributing £m to feed these objects of his disgust who are, oh yes, actual human beings.Weaposre now at the stage where, when a footballer starts a campaign to feed hungry children, the Department for Education rejects his request, and an official spokesman issues a refusal on his behalf, the PM claims not to have known anything about it in the apparent belief this makes him sound like a better PM. Within hours, the Number  spin machine had called the PM a liar, in the apparent belief that made him sound better. Weaposre not so much through the looking glass, as exiled to the Phantom Zone and outside the normal space-time continuum.We donapost even get General Zodaposs hair to admire, or Ursaaposs eyeliner. We are incarcerated with the political equivalent of Non, a man neither as focused nor as fully-ing as the average hamster. As Ron Atkinson once said, this is a game all about the two Ms - movement and positioning. Perhaps Johnson will respond to the absolute schooling Rashford has given him in the power of popularity by trying to be more like a footballer. Maybe weaposll see the PM adopt a man-bun, or diamond ear-studs, or Sky Sports-style fake roars of crowd approval. If this should happen, let us all pray we are not also subjected to a gruesome kiss-and-tell. But while Johnsonaposs greatest strength is his sociopathic indference to the truth, Rashfordaposs is the ability to see where he came from, and make the worst parts good. His mum Melanie is rightly proud as punch that her boyaposs former hunger has put food in the bellies of millions of children. THATaposS how you bling up the bad.Johnson, on the other hand, sees no harm in where he came from. No damage done by paternal adultery, marriage breakdown, or elite schooling in which children are told they have a right to run the world. He never learns from his past, the forced apologies, the firings, the losses of political capital gt-wrapped and delivered by his brilliant strategist. He just carries on lying by the seat of his pants, and why not. It has got him this far. But when a footballer announces he has helped to feed million of the countryaposs most vulnerable people, when a -year-old with no experience of politics is more diplomatic, powerful, and loquacious than the PM, when the government is in such disarray that they make the Football Ladsapos Alliance look sane and organised, then whataposs the point of Boris   Johnsonaposs appeal is based on his entertainment value. His current jape is presenting us with a charnel house, built and then filled by ethnic minorities, while he capers around telling us statues matter more than black lives. If only heaposd paid attention while studying classics, heaposd know thataposs tragedy, not comedy. He has not produced the Brexit promised, and which the majority of Britons want. He is not levelling up so much as carpet-bombing everywhere. The Red Wall he seized is collapsing at the same time as the Blue Base he canapost bail the disappointment out of quickly enough.The purpose of a Prime Minister is to be first among equals. To lead, idealise, and effect. Rashford, who has none of the privilege Johnson enjoys, has done better than him at all three. Stanley should ask for a refund from Eton - the school fees were, clearly, spaffed up the wall.

story: NewsPeople in their s and s could be poorer when they retire due to coronavirusOne in five people have experienced deteriorating physical health, while a third say their mental health has been affected by the pandemic and the lockdown measuresShareCommentsByTricia PhillipsPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JUN NewsA lost generation will be in a worse state of health when they retire, experts warn " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPeople in their s and s could retire poorer and in worse health than the generation before them because of the pandemic, campaigners warn. One in five in this “lost generation” have suffered deteriorating physical health during the lockdown, and a third say their mental health has worsened. Nearly half believe their personal finances will take a hit in the next year, found an Ipsos Mori poll for the Centre for Ageing Better. The charity’s chief Anna Dixon said: “This group are being ignored when it comes to proposed actions to support the recovery. At the same time, it’s clear this group also face serious risks to their health.“If this generation continues to be an afterthought in the coronavirus recovery we’ll see a lost generation entering retirement in poorer health and worse financial circumstances than those before them.” It came amid suggestions that Chancellor Rishi Sunak was considering suspending the Tories’ triple-lock pensions manesto pledge.The mechanism ensures the state pension rises in line with the highest of wages, inflation or .%, so any change would save the Treasury billions – but also risks angering millions of pensioners. Experts believe a temporary suspension is inevitable unless the Government is prepared to pay a massive bill next year. There are signs that the bounce back in wages for furloughed workers could push up average earnings and put pensioners in line for an % increase. There is also uncertainty over inflation. Boris Johnson yesterday warned of “tough times ahead” as ministers faced pressure to increase support for some of the poorest households.The triple lock could be replaced with a lower guaranteed minimum of % or .%, or a “double lock” – raising the pension by the highest of inflation or earnings growth, but with no guaranteed minimum.  Retirement expert and former Tory Pensions Minister Ros Altmann said: “The Government absolutely must protect pensioners... However, all policy decisions are likely to be revisited in light of the health and economic crisis. “It is important not to rush to hasty conclusions, but I hope [people] will consider the way the triple lock actually works and objectively assess whether it may have run its course.” Downing Street played down the suggestion the triple lock could be suspended or scrapped. But a No source said: “These are unique and challenging economic circumstances and we can’t hide from that.”A spokesman for Labour leader Keir Starmer said: “We’ve long said the triple lock is an important means of addressing the relatively low state pension by international standards.”The TUC also warned the triple lock must stay because our state pension is one of the lowest in the developed world.

title: schools cant fully reopen september
story: NewsSchools cant fully reopen in September under current distancing rules, unions warnTeachers leaders called for public buildings to be taken over for extra classrooms, and warned blended learning may still be necessary - as they demanded a plan from the governmentShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsUnions have warned home schooling could have to continue" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEnglandaposs schools wonapost be able to fully reopen in September under current distancing rules, unions warned today. Teachersapos leaders demanded public buildings are taken over for extra classroom space - saying there just isnapost room to bring back whole schools of -strong mini-classes. And they warned children may still need to rely on blended learning - a mix of homeschooling and attending in person - beyond September. Unions clashed with Tory MPs as they demanded a clear plan from the government - insisting they were simply trying to follow scientic advice. Boris Johnson wants all Englandaposs children back in school from September after six months of coronavirus disruption.But plans to bring in years R,  and  are mired in chaos, with a third of Englandaposs primary schools still not doing so by June . And plans to bring back years , ,  and  by the start of July had to be dropped after officials accepted there wasnapost enough space. Distancing rules say children must be taught in bubbles of  kids, each in a separate room. That has left schools scrambling to find space and rope in support staff to lead lessons. Mary Bousted, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, warned MPs something had to give. Askedschools could open fully in September under current restrictions, she told the Education Committee: If the Government retains its social distancing rules then they canapost.  So thataposs why we then need to look at an education recovery plan, which is focused on more than school buildings. “We’ve got one, the NEU has got one, about increasing the physical footprint of the school, about increasing the numbers of teachers available to teach smaller classes, and about a national plan for blended learning. Jon Richards, National Secretary at UNISON, said you have to have facilities set up and there were still “serious issues” around cleaning and canteens. He added: I’m hoping we’ll be open to reopen schools, as many as we can, in September. But as Mary said, it will depend to an extent on what the government says.  Julie McCulloch, Director of Policy at the ASCL union, said: If it’s at all possible and considered safe then absolutely we want all children to be back in school from September. That is by far the best solution. But as colleagues have said we’re not able to do that at the moment within the government’s own protective measures guidance. The maths just doesn’t work. If you can only have up to  children in a class, and you’re bringing back all children, you need twice as many classrooms and twice as many teachers. Now clearly there are conversations we can have about how we might be able to have more space and how we might be able to increase the teaching workforce, but neither of those is straightforward. She added the best outcome -the science says that this is safe and appropriate - would be to have all children back with some of those measures relaxed in September.  Dr Patrick Roach, General Secretary of the NASUWT, added: Schools should open as quickly as possible, we’ve been very very clear about that. We want to see clarity from government about what the expectations are from September in terms of what schooling will look like. The union chiefs have hit back at Tory MPs in a furious clash over whether schools are safe. Tensions bubbled over at the Education Committee, where an MP accused unions of running a political campaign to keep schools shut. Tory Jonathan Gullis, a former teacher, accused unions of breathing fear into parents and making them think schools are death traps. The MP blasted: I am absolutely outraged at the sheer damage the unions have done to the teaching profession. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman insisted today: The PM has set out a very clear message… school is safe and he wants parents to send their children back to school. But the four unions being quizzed by the committee hit back - and demanded more clarity and action from the government. Union chiefs warned it was impossible to bring all pupils back while following guidance to keep them socially distanced and in -pupil classes.

A study of , adults found one third have been putting extra money aside - an average of £ - since lockdown began. More than two thirds of thoseare saving more by putting away the money they would normally spend on eating out, while almost half have banked refunds from cancelled holidays. And  per cent have saved the money they would have spent commuting to work. A fortunate three in  adults said they are currently financially better off than before the Covid- pandemic, while  per cent have managed to maintain their level of wealth. It also emerged spending habits have changed dramatically since the start of the lockdown, with the average adult £ better off after cutting back on unnecessary things such as clothing, takeaway coffee, eating out and entertaining. Maitham Mohsin, head of savings at Skipton Building Society, which commissioned the research, said: These are financially challenging times for many, so it is reassuring to see that some adults are able to set aside savings for a rainy day, to make the best use of their reduced savings. This pandemic is witnessing a change in attitudes to wealth, savings, and money - as people, are more than before understanding the real need to have a financial buffer for unforeseen eventualities such as furlough or job loss. Many people have had to take payment holidays on mortgages, and dip into savings to get by over these last two or three months never before has a savings pot been so needed. And this in itself is likely to encourage a more sensible approach to financial planning moving forward.  The study also found that Brits have seen their spending reduce on things like fuel, commuting and alcohol, which is helping them to save more than before. It emerged those who are saving more during lockdown have also been able to do so because they are spending less on childcare costs , family days outand birthday presents . Instead, more has been spent on cleaning products , TV streaming servicesand books or magazines to pass the time . However, the survey also highlights that one quarter of adults are worse off financially since the pandemic struck. One in four have had to accept a pay reduction since the crisis began, and  per cent of those polled, via OnePoll, have taken either a loan or mortgage holiday - or both. It also emerged  per cent of adults have had to dip into their savings during lockdown - spending an average of £ to pay for essential bills , foodand council tax . But regardless of a personaposs current financial situation, six in  adults now say they are more likely to put money away for a rainy day, rather than spend it when they do have it. And while a fth are putting less money into savings at the moment, eight in  say theyaposd feel even more nervousthey didnapost have any rainy day fund to fall back on. In particular,  per cent of adults like to have savings for unexpected or emergency payments, and  per cent like to put money aside for home improvements.

story: NewsEerie cottage left frozen in time with paper from Titanic sinking still on tableA cottage left untouched since it was abandoned gives a glimpse into le more than  years ago after the previous owner lived a solitary le among the relics of the pastShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsAudience Writer:,  JUN NewsThe home is in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
