Hugh Gutty McGlone had a club career with Newbridge spanning  seasons. His younger years coincided with a bright spell in the clubs history. He spoke to Michael McMullan about losing championships, winning the John McLaughlin Cup and building for the future. Gutty McGlone is no dferent to any other competitor. Defeat hits him like a sledgehammer. It festers to the very pit of his stomach. Its county final afternoon in  and an emerging Lavey team savour the sweet aroma of victory. Inside, in the corner of the Glen dressing room, McGlone reflects. The remnants of their - to - defeat get tossed through his mind again, something only disappointment can do. googletag.cmd.push The pitter patter of water in the adjoining shower area stops. The noise you only hear above the eerie silence of failure. John McErlain, Liam Devlin and Damian Barton emerge. Their confab draws a common conclusion. They had left three titles behind them. Next year will be dferent. In , -year-old McGlones debut season, the Bridge didnt stand up for themselves in the championship against Ballinderry, before losing the game. Eamonn Coleman was manager and after making him a regular from the mid-point of the league, Hugh wasnt selected for the championship defeat to the Shamrocks, with Coleman later confessing it was about protecting him for a career ahead. He just wasnt ready. googletag.cmd.push Three years earlier, torn ligaments in McGlones right ankle, sustained in school action for St Pius, worked out for the best. “Before that, I couldnt kick with my weak foot,” recalls Hugh, who would later coach at underage and engineer the foundations for the current senior team. He remembers the late Brendan Convery insisting on ato school training once he could walk, before arming him with a bag of balls. “Convery made me stand on the and kick every ball into the goals with my left foot. The next week, he made me go to the ,” McGlone clearly remembers. The man who managed Laveys All-Ireland winning team was developing McGlone without him even knowing. “I gradually got stronger and stronger and thats where I ended up playing at left corner back for the Bridge seniors at , because I had two feet and was able to go up the line...that was all down to Brendan Convery.” St Pius annexed an U Vocational Schools All-Ireland, with McGlone on board. A year later, in , Derry minors, who played most of the game with  men following the first-minute dismissal of Gregory McCloskey, were beaten by a point in Newry by Down, who went on to win the All-Ireland. McGlone lined out at corner back and a year more experienced, had established himself as a regular on the Bridge senior team. Once again, they crossed paths with Ballinderry. After having previously taken two games to beat Magherafelt, they met the Shamrocks in the infamous semi-final replay encounter at Greenlough. Newbridge came through to play Dungiven in a final.  The Newbridge team pictured before the  Derry senior final It wasnt to be. Newbridge were going to stand their ground this time. Familiarity bred contempt and after another tempestuous battle with the Shamrocks, which saw pitch invasions, Newbridge were thrown out leaving Dungiven to be awarded the title in the boardroom. Losing was becoming a habit and in the aftermath of their  defeat, before leaving Glen, they made a pact. “We are going to learn from this,” McGlone relays of the collective dressing room message. “We left one , we didnt get playing in oneand now we have lost one. We are not going to lose another one.” *** You earned your corn at Newbridge training. The championship jersey wasnt handed out willy nilly. Gutty McGlone, the youngest of seven boys in a house of  children, would leave home for the short walk to the hall for a Saturday pre-championship meeting before the  final. He was unnecessarily uneasy. “Im not sure of my position here,” McGlone thought. He was ever-present and never substituted during the year, but Stephen Walls, an All-Ireland minor winner with Derry in , was breathing down McGlones neck. “Thats the class of player we had on the bench. I knew I had played well, but because of the competition at the time in the Newbridge team, I was thinking I could get a gunk here I knew the pressure was on, thats why you had to perform.” It was an era that secured back-to-back senior leagues in  and , as well as three reserve championships inside five years. “This just wasnt about the senior team, those three teams were the pinnacle of us winning thechampionship in ,” McGlone stated, in no uncertain terms. Before emphasising it again. “We played games at training during ...it was a senior team against a reserve team. We struggled to beat them, so that shows you the class of talent we had in Newbridge at that time.” McGlone name-checks Mickey McGrogan and Shane Doherty as some of the forwards who trotted into his left corner back area in training games, players not even listed on the -man match-day  for the final. And they gave him his fill of it. “Then, you had big Hugh McGrogan, Paudis Da, running around at midfield, kicking the shite out of Damian Barton. There was no respect given whatsoever.” It was dog eat dog. And it needed to be. This was to be the year. “Rabbiand Sam , our managers, picked  seniors against  reserves, so we would learn how to play together in games.” The seniors never overran their reserve counterparts. “Not a chance,” Gutty stresses. The seniors never won by any more than four or five points, with the reserves winning the odd game. It worked wonders when it mattered. “Any time we were down by a couple of points , that team didnt know when it was beat. Now it mightnt have been the silkiest team, but boys just never quit,” Hugh admits. After three years of knocking on the door, with the pain of defeat lingering like a dark cloud and with the younger players beginning to mature, it was time to die dog or shite the licence. *** There was another ingredient. Sam Bateson is described by McGlone as the tactician with his managerial partner Thomas Fullerton also knowing his football. The perfect match. Fullerton, a reserve winning captain, was playing with McGlone in a  Graham Cup game. Magherafelt were running them ragged and led by six or seven points at the interval. “It was one of the first times I saw we had steel and other teams didnt have, Thomas went f**king ballistic at half-time,” Gutty remembers. It was a watershed moment. The law was laid down. Like the rest of the team, McGlone imposed himself. They were like men possessed and won the game well. “I was niggling with my man and remember him filling my mouth when we began to get on top,” said McGlone, who walked off the pitch with blood running out of his nose. “Hes not playing football in the next round, but we are,” Rabbi uttered to him, with a laugh. “Thats when I thought, the odd slap in the mouth doesnt matter, as long as you come out on the right side of it.” Another piece of valuable advice was dished out by John McErlain who often played in front of him on the left wing. In his early days, McGlone would often hoof the ball to safety. As a young buck, and under pressure, it was safer than getting caught in possession. “John roared at me one day in a league game,” he remembers. “I was told to either use the ball up the wing or just lay it off. Its those wee things that helps you when you are growing up.” As the  season began to grow, Newbridge beat  champions Bellaghy in the first round, followed by a hard-earned victory over  winners Glenullin and a semi-final encounter win over Banagher. It took them to the decider against neighbours Castledawson. Midway through the first-half, Brian McErlain was sent off. In the reshuffle, Damian Barton dropped back to centre-back. “Damian was that good with the long pass, that we didnt really have to attack and we could keep six at the back,” McGlone said of his captain. “He was able to get the ball to Devand Paddy Barton up there. On that day, I thought the Newbridge defence was outstanding...everybody. It was tight, it was hard hitting and Castledawson didnt get going.” They knew that Eamonn Heaney wasnt going to make Dawsons starting team, but would play a part. He had played at full-back in the  final, but was now threw in at full-forward to help rescue the game. It wasnt long before Rabbi was out over the sideline to instruct McGlone to do a marking job on Colm McKee for the remainder of the game, having blotted out the substituted Mickey Hughes. “Neither me or Colm touched the ball, but the management had trust in us. I was the youngest man on our team and they were happy to leave me on their county man.” Having played in three county finals and losing two of them, McGlone – who has a memory for detail that matches his enthusiasm – always remembers the call for stewards to pick up their end of match positions. “Its one of the worst feelings you could have as a footballer when you are getting beat by two or three points,” he recalls. One year on from hearing it against Lavey in , they led Castledawson when the announcement bellowed out. He remembers dampening Eoin Gribbins joy at the thought of having their clutches on that elusive championship. “One goal and they are back in it,” McGlone warned him. “In the Lavey game, it seemed to last  seconds until the final whistle, but when it was called that year , we were ahead...it seemed like an eternity until the whistle.” Newbridge were not to be caught. They kept their promise from  months earlier and Damian Barton collected the John McLaughlin Cup after a -year gap, for their th and last title. From McGlones recollection, win lose or draw, Wilfie Garvin, Mick McKenna, Jim Gilmore, Seamus and Dermot Doherty, Owen and Willie Gribbin would always be in the Newbridge dressing room after games. They were part of the teams fabric. “I remember those boys being in the day we won it and I was never as glad to see it. Its one of the wee things I will always remember.” Later in the evening the team went for a meal at the ONeill Arms in Toome, before heading back to Newbridge Hall for the celebrations. McGlone wasnt a teetotaller, he enjoyed a drink like most of the others and it was curbed during the championship preparations. “I never touched drink the night we won the championship, not one pint,” Gutty said of his premeditated decision. “I wanted to savour the whole thing and not to be talking to the older men around the club and me maybe half tight.” The next two or three days were dferent. Between the Elk and the Thatch, it was party central. On the Monday night, the squad did a tour of Newbridge on the back of Mick McKennas lorry.   Derry champions Newbridge “Everyone was on the back of er,” Gutty laughs. “We went down to Toome to pick up Stephen McErlain and then did every road in Newbridge. You wouldve thought there were  cars behind us. For the next two or three days, I dont think we sobered.” They were at the top of Everest. But surprisingly, being one of the most consistent teams of the time, it was the only senior championship that crop won. In , they took the foot off the pedal and lost to Ballinascreen in the semi-final who were beaten by eventual All-Ireland champions Lavey. “In  Eugene Young came in to manage us and we got to the final. We missed two goals and theyscored two goals, that was the dference in us winning another one.” While picking up intermediate silverware in the interim, he recalls the disappointment of relegation in  after surviving for three or four seasons in play-offs. “To start your career with a championship medal in your pocket at  or , struggling and relegation was tough. To go from being top of the pile...from walking around behind bands, to relegation, it was tough.” McGlone picked up an intermediate medal in , but when the same title ed five years later, he had stepped away from the seniors, choosing to play with the reserves. Gutty was coaxed out back into the senior ranks by manager Gavin Devlin for an impact role at full-forward, using his guile to pull full-back lines of position. A dead leg suffered in , a niggle that never fully cleared up told McGlone it was time to pull the pin. In retirement, he was never going to step away from the game he loved. The buzz in his voice, with every word dancing, speaks volumes for his fanaticism for football. He stayed on as long as he could, with the club having little youth coming through. It was time to dig new foundations and survey the lie of the land in the local school. “There were big numbers from U down, so we decided wed start with the underage,” states Hugh, who had the help of Neil Young, Martin Gribbin and Gabriel Farren. It was the clubs first U U group, as part of a unofficial South Derry underage initiative. With clubs coaching for three weeks and playing a blitz on the fourth week. “We couldnt believe it, when all  of them turned up at the first session,” he said of a group that supplied seven players to the senior team beaten by Slaughtneil in last years championship. “By U, CKcame in to help. He had taken teams around Newbridge that boysdidnt want, hed step up. Noel McPeake and Sean McKenna came in too and helped.” After winning the U B league and championship, McGlone took a break before ing at minor level and asked for another step up in class. At the pre-season meeting he asked those in the room with two B medals to stand up. “About  percent stood up and when asked who has at least one , and the rest of them stood,” McGlone states. It was time to move up to the A grade. In their first game, they were away to Slaughtneil and unlucky not to beat a team who were U champions two years earlier. After losing heavily to Magherafelt in the Hughes McElwee Cup, the league game between them finished in a draw.  The  Newbridge U U  “If you win a Byou have to step up to A. We were not going to win anything. If we played somebody and there was  points in it and we played them a second day and there was two points in it, we are progressing.” McGlone expressed. He was looking further down the track. His sons are now playing on the senior team, he helped shape. In recent years, they picked up another intermediate title and are back in the top flight. Hopefully to stay. “Now we have a  again that,nurtured right, can dine at the top table again. Hopefully...I am one of the men that is going in around the dressing room in the next five or six years like the older boys did when we won.” Guttys fanaticism has never diluted, nor is it likely to. Thousands of companies have been taking advantage of an unprecedented package of UK Government support to protect jobs and support businesses during the coronavirus outbreak. The financial support is helping firms across the nation to adapt, innovate and protect jobs. Here are two examples of how companies have been helped, and what support is available. NORTHERN IRELAND IN NUMBERS , jobs furloughed through the Coronavirus Jobs Retention Scheme up to May  , claims amounting to pound million through the Self- Employment Income Support Scheme up to May  Across the whole UK  per cent of those eligible for SEISS made a claim. When Covid- struck, Newtownards baby product manufacturer Shnuggle’s owners Sinead and Adam Murphy were prepared thanks to advice from their export colleagues in China. Sinead said: “We reduced our out-goings, put on pause our marketing spend in the business. We just tried to protect the cash that we had. “The first impact was our customers that we sell to in Asia. They all went into lockdown so our orders and sales to them stopped. But also a lot of our production happens out in Asia so our factories went into lockdown. googletag.cmd.push “Luckily we had bought a lot of stock beforehand. We were so relieved that we had, at least we could carry on trading with our UK and European customers.” With around half of the company’s sales in the UK and Ireland and half in the export business, Shnuggle had to rely on their local retail-base. Sinead continued: “Baby items were classed as essential goods which was a huge relief to us. This meant as long as we could socially distance within the warehouse we could continue trading and selling online. All of our business is supplying other retailers like John Lewis, Mamas and Papas, Amazon. But our online sales actually grew because everyone was at home and maybe an element of panic buying.”  CASH HELP: The Shnuggle team Shnuggle took advantage of the furlough and Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Schemeschemes. Sinead said: “We furloughed five out of our  team, and were able to access the Business Interruption loan through Ulster Bank. “We were relieved to get the money in quickly, so we weren’t worrying about paying wages or our biggest overhead was our suppliers in China who were calling in all of their debts. “That was our biggest headache and stress, we owed signicant amounts of money to them and we didn’t have the cash as we needed time to sell our products.” Shnuggle also received a pound, Small Business Grant. Adam said: “Furloughing was brilliant, and the CBILS was the one that was the best for us because it meant that we could keep all our suppliers happy. “So even though we had a temporary dip in our sales, and obviously the inventory was sitting there ready to sell, it just kept us solvent and the cash flow moving. It’s really going to help us trade out of it, andall goes well, we should be able to get back into a reasonably strong cash position within the next six to  months. The loans coming in helped us to sleep at night.” The Government schemes also gave Sinead and Adam the freedom to ersy into the PPE market and the development of HeroShield Ltd, enabling local firms to unite to develop a protective face covering for key workers. This non-profit company designs, produces and distributes reusable visors.   ‘It’s surprisingly easy and money arrives quickly’ CASE STUDY  Q-MASS An unprecedented package of UK Government financial support has helped firms like Q-Mass in East Kilbride weather the coronavirus crisis. Director Ronnie Robertson said lockdown hit his company’s order book, but the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme has been vital to help them hang on to their valued staff. Ronnie said: “Before this, we had quite a good order book, with three to four months of work planned, so we were pretty worried where it was going to take us.” At first, he was worried how he would keep Q-Mass’  staff on the payroll, but then the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme was announced. It offers UK Government support to pay  per cent of staff’s wages up to pound, a month, and the scheme has now been extended until the end of October. Q-Mass manufactures bespoke parts for the oil, gas and defence industry so staff training is important. Ronnie said: “Our staff are very highly skilled. We’ve gathered a bunch of people here and trained them up and taken on apprentices. We do a lot of training, we’ve got good people, we train them a lot and we want to hang on to them.” He found applying for the furlough scheme quick and straightforward. He said: “It was surprisingly easy and we were surprised that the money came through relatively quickly.” Now staff at the firm who’ve been furloughed are gradually ing to work, with strict safety measures in place. Ronnie said: “We’ve put a day sht back on and we’ve still got a few office people working at home, with quite a few still on furlough.  ‘SURPRISINGLY EASY’: Q-Mass director Ronnie Robertson praises the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme “We’re just ticking over. We’re trying to cover our costs every month, trying to break even, to stay still. We’re looking at it thatwe can stay still we’re doing very well.” And because of the size of the building, maintaining a two-metre distance hasn’t been a problem for ing staff. Ronnie said: “It’s been really easy. We’ve got a big workshop with wide corridors and we’ve got a lot of the doors propped open internally so no-one has to touch doors or handles. We’ve got a few toilet areas with restrictions on them and a couple of one-way corridors, but the offices are open plan, so there’s no real need for people to be near each other. The workshop’s a big, wide-open space and we have to keep cleaning things like photocopiers and touch screens, but it’s been quite straightforward.” Now Ronnie’s looking forward to a brighter future. He said: “I feel like we’re on the side of the valley and we’re looking across to the other side and it looks absolutely fantastic.” Money for business and staff Here are some examples of the support available for businesses and workers. middot The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme has enabled businesses to put employees on a period of temporary leaveand apply for a UK Government grant to cover  per cent of those workers’ usual monthly wage costs, up to pound, a month. middot The Self-Employment Income Support Scheme will allow eligible self-employed iniduals to claim a taxable grant of  per cent of their average monthly profits, up to pound,. middot UK VAT-registered firms have been given the option to defer VAT payments until the end of June. There will be no interest or penalties on any amount deferred.  middot Commercial tenants who cannot pay their rent because of coronavirus will be protected from eviction. middot The UK Government’s Bounce Back Loans Scheme provides loans of up to pound, to small businesses, with a  per cent government-backed guarantee for lenders. middot The Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme is available for loans or finance of up to poundm. The UK Government will provide the lender with an  per cent guarantee to support the lending. middot The Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme will repay employers the current rate of Statutory Sick Pay they pay current or former employees for sickness starting on or after March , . middot The Future Fund will issue loans between pound, to pound million to innovative companies which are facing financing dficulties due to the coronavirus outbreak. Thousands of companies have been taking advantage of an unprecedented package of UK Government support to protect jobs and support businesses during the coronavirus outbreak. The financial support is helping firms across the nation to adapt, innovate and protect jobs. Here are two examples of how companies have been helped, and what support is available. NORTHERN IRELAND IN NUMBERS , jobs furloughed through the Coronavirus Jobs Retention Scheme up to May  , claims amounting to pound million through the Self- Employment Income Support Scheme up to May  Across the whole UK  per cent of those eligible for SEISS made a claim. The average value of a claim is pound, googletag.cmd.push Source: Her Majesty’s Treasury CASE STUDY  SHNUGGLE  Planning, forward-thinking and invaluable help from the UK Government has enabled a Northern Ireland firm to ersy and remain solvent. When Covid- struck, Newtownards baby product manufacturer Shnuggle’s owners Sinead and Adam Murphy were prepared thanks to advice from their export colleagues in China. Sinead said: “We reduced our out-goings, put on pause our marketing spend in the business. We just tried to protect the cash that we had. “The first impact was our customers that we sell to in Asia. They all went into lockdown so our orders and sales to them stopped. But also a lot of our production happens out in Asia so our factories went into lockdown. googletag.cmd.push “Luckily we had bought a lot of stock beforehand. We were so relieved that we had, at least we could carry on trading with our UK and European customers.” With around half of the company’s sales in the UK and Ireland and half in the export business, Shnuggle had to rely on their local retail-base. Sinead continued: “Baby items were classed as essential goods which was a huge relief to us. This meant as long as we could socially distance within the warehouse we could continue trading and selling online. All of our business is supplying other retailers like John Lewis, Mamas and Papas, Amazon. But our online sales actually grew because everyone was at home and maybe an element of panic buying.”  CASH HELP: The Shnuggle team Shnuggle took advantage of the furlough and Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Schemeschemes. Sinead said: “We furloughed five out of our  team, and were able to access the Business Interruption loan through Ulster Bank. “We were relieved to get the money in quickly, so we weren’t worrying about paying wages or our biggest overhead was our suppliers in China who were calling in all of their debts. “That was our biggest headache and stress, we owed signicant amounts of money to them and we didn’t have the cash as we needed time to sell our products.” Shnuggle also received a pound, Small Business Grant. Adam said: “Furloughing was brilliant, and the CBILS was the one that was the best for us because it meant that we could keep all our suppliers happy. “So even though we had a temporary dip in our sales, and obviously the inventory was sitting there ready to sell, it just kept us solvent and the cash flow moving. It’s really going to help us trade out of it, andall goes well, we should be able to get back into a reasonably strong cash position within the next six to  months. The loans coming in helped us to sleep at night.” The Government schemes also gave Sinead and Adam the freedom to ersy into the PPE market and the development of HeroShield Ltd, enabling local firms to unite to develop a protective face covering for key workers. This non-profit company designs, produces and distributes reusable visors.   ‘It’s surprisingly easy and money arrives quickly’ CASE STUDY  Q-MASS An unprecedented package of UK Government financial support has helped firms like Q-Mass in East Kilbride weather the coronavirus crisis. Director Ronnie Robertson said lockdown hit his company’s order book, but the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme has been vital to help them hang on to their valued staff. Ronnie said: “Before this, we had quite a good order book, with three to four months of work planned, so we were pretty worried where it was going to take us.” At first, he was worried how he would keep Q-Mass’  staff on the payroll, but then the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme was announced. It offers UK Government support to pay  per cent of staff’s wages up to pound, a month, and the scheme has now been extended until the end of October. Q-Mass manufactures bespoke parts for the oil, gas and defence industry so staff training is important. Ronnie said: “Our staff are very highly skilled. We’ve gathered a bunch of people here and trained them up and taken on apprentices. We do a lot of training, we’ve got good people, we train them a lot and we want to hang on to them.” He found applying for the furlough scheme quick and straightforward. He said: “It was surprisingly easy and we were surprised that the money came through relatively quickly.” Now staff at the firm who’ve been furloughed are gradually ing to work, with strict safety measures in place. Ronnie said: “We’ve put a day sht back on and we’ve still got a few office people working at home, with quite a few still on furlough.  ‘SURPRISINGLY EASY’: Q-Mass director Ronnie Robertson praises the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme “We’re just ticking over. We’re trying to cover our costs every month, trying to break even, to stay still. We’re looking at it thatwe can stay still we’re doing very well.” And because of the size of the building, maintaining a two-metre distance hasn’t been a problem for ing staff. Ronnie said: “It’s been really easy. We’ve got a big workshop with wide corridors and we’ve got a lot of the doors propped open internally so no-one has to touch doors or handles. We’ve got a few toilet areas with restrictions on them and a couple of one-way corridors, but the offices are open plan, so there’s no real need for people to be near each other. The workshop’s a big, wide-open space and we have to keep cleaning things like photocopiers and touch screens, but it’s been quite straightforward.” Now Ronnie’s looking forward to a brighter future. He said: “I feel like we’re on the side of the valley and we’re looking across to the other side and it looks absolutely fantastic.” Money for business and staff Here are some examples of the support available for businesses and workers. middot The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme has enabled businesses to put employees on a period of temporary leaveand apply for a UK Government grant to cover  per cent of those workers’ usual monthly wage costs, up to pound, a month. middot The Self-Employment Income Support Scheme will allow eligible self-employed iniduals to claim a taxable grant of  per cent of their average monthly profits, up to pound,. middot UK VAT-registered firms have been given the option to defer VAT payments until the end of June. There will be no interest or penalties on any amount deferred.  middot Commercial tenants who cannot pay their rent because of coronavirus will be protected from eviction. middot The UK Government’s Bounce Back Loans Scheme provides loans of up to pound, to small businesses, with a  per cent government-backed guarantee for lenders. middot The Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme is available for loans or finance of up to poundm. The UK Government will provide the lender with an  per cent guarantee to support the lending. middot The Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme will repay employers the current rate of Statutory Sick Pay they pay current or former employees for sickness starting on or after March , . middot The Future Fund will issue loans between pound, to pound million to innovative companies which are facing financing dficulties due to the coronavirus outbreak. A nurse who has lived in Derry for fteen years has shared her family’s experience of racism in the city. Beverly Simpson moved from Guyana in South America to Derry in  to help the ‘failing health system’. She has two sons and a daughter, who was born in Derry. Mrs Simpson was one of the speakers at the Black Lives Matter rally on Saturday in Derrys Guildhall Square. Speaking to the Derry News this week, Beverly said she felt compelled to speak at the event as people from Black, Asian and Minority Ethniccommunities need a ‘safe outlet to express their feelings’. googletag.cmd.push In relation to opposition to the rally taking place, she believes that certain political parties mobilised the PSNI and in doing so ‘aggravated the situation’. Mrs Simpson said she and her daughter Jada were approached by police before reaching the Guildhall and again by three officers while standing there. “The police were intimidating us, she said. It was a safe space, controlled, we had a voice. “I thought, did police officers just see the colour of my skin and approach me. “They weren’t approaching everyone. Like every organisation there’s an element that think they’re superior. “The rally wasn’t even started when we were approached and they didn’t give us the option of going home. googletag.cmd.push “They annoyed us that much it made us more determined to stay.” She added: “They were trying to put a lid on an active volcano, it will still erupt, but instead of erupting in a controlled manner it will erupt all over the place. “Let it be addressed in a controlled environment, in schools or in church. “People should be able to speak about racism, it’s not going away no matter how many lids are put on it.” Since moving to the city, Mrs Simpson claimed that her entire family have been subjected to racism. “All three of my children have experienced racism, including my -year-old,” she said. “In Derry it may be subtle, not open or staring you in the face, but it’s there and unless we actually speak about it, people get away with it and continue to do it. “Don’t get me wrong, you have people everywhere who are good and bad, you have people in Derry who are not racist. “It’s about people’s moral compass, your ethics and what you value. “Children are born innocent and unless you teach them to hate, and teach them racism, they don’t see the person as another colour. “It is something that is learnt and unless we address our own personal prejudices we’ll get nowhere.” From April  to March , there were  racist incidents, resulting in  crimes, in Northern Ireland. Of those,  occurred in the Derry and Strabane policing district, an increase of  on the previous year. It’s understood that many incidents go unreported. For Mrs Simpson’s daughter Jada, race was never an issue until two years ago. Mrs Simpson said her friends at school are all white and ‘she never saw herself as dferent’. However, an incident in  changed her attitude. “She was at the bus station trying to board a bus when the driver shut the door in her face and drove off, leaving her standing there.” Mrs Simpson said that after viewing footage of the incident, the company apologised and the driver was said to have been disciplined. She continued: “It’s there, and unless each company can do like the bus company, address the inidual who is the rotten egg instead of hiding it, and condoning it or trying to cover it up. Address it openly.” Following the incident, the family felt that somebody had listened to them, but Mrs Simpson said a lot of people are afraid to speak out. “Where does that anger go, where does that hurt go, it stays and grows and infiltrates society.” Confirming the incident, a Translink spokesperson stated: “A complaint was received on thSeptember  at Foyle Street bus station. “This was acknowledged, investigated and followed up. “Translink’s Dignity at Work policy, in which all staff are trained on their induction, makes it clear that we are fully committed to creating a harmonious working environment in which all employees are treated with respect and dignity, regardless of race, colour, ethnic or national origins. “This equally applies to how our staff are expected to treat passengers.” In response to criticism that now is not the right time to hold protests, Mrs Simpson said: “Coronavirus is affecting everyone. It’s affecting the Black, Asian and ethnic minority community more. “We’re being marginalised anyway, we’re being segregated anyway, whether by a natural cause or a man-made cause so give us a chance to speak in a safe space.” The level of support on Saturday surprised Mrs Simpson and she said she was ‘proud’ that people ‘challenged themselves’ by turning out. This is what the future of our pubs are expected to look like. These exclusive photographs show the special screens which have been erected at Tinneys Bar in Derry. All other pubs are expected to install similar screens between staff and customers as the hospitality sector reopens following the coronavirus lockdown.  A local blinds shop has been assisting Derry bars and businesses as they prepare to reopen safely. Ace Blinds have been operating in the Derry area, serving the community for over five years and employing local people. As businesses adjust to the so-called new normal after lockdown, they have to enforce social distancing and come up with innovative ways to protect their customers. googletag.cmd.push Therefore, Ace Blinds has fitted ‘COVID- roller shields’ in local bars and the orders have been mounting from other businesses in the city. “It has gone a bit crazy at the minute and we have already taken  orders for bars,” says John Kelly of Ace Blinds. It is new territory for Ace Blinds in terms of the material they are using. “The plastic material suits bars great as they can be moved up and down very easily, not like perspex, and they are a lot easier on the eye for customers, so more friendly. They can be attached to suspension ceilings with a special clip so no drillingneeds be. googletag.cmd.push “The material is easily cleaned, you just hold the bottom bar and wipe clean and it can be secured to bars or the groundneeded.” The company has fitted the bathroom at EI Engineering to separate sinks which provides an extra layer of protection for workers. Other businesses in the town have come to them with dferent proposals which they’re working through together. This week, the Economy Minister Dianne Dodds announced that all non-essential goods retailers in Northern Ireland can re-open from tomorrow. Pubs and restaurants are expected to follow suit in July. Confirming the ‘major step forward’, the Minister said: “The pandemic has had a devastating impact on the local economy. The recovery has already begun and it is time now for the pace to accelerate. The re-opening of all goods retail outlets will be a huge part of this. “The safety of staff and customers is of course paramount. All retailers must be able to implement measures that minimise the risk to their staff and to the people who visit their stores. “We will be co-existing with this virus for some time to come so it is vital that we continue to adhere to guidance to work and live safely.” The Minister added: “The re-opening of our local shopping sector is a signicant step forward in the Executive’s pathway to recovery. I and my Executive colleagues remain committed to moving forward in the recovery while at all times keeping the health, wellbeing and safety of people at the centre and being transparent in our approach.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Hotels, bars, restaurants and cafes in Northern Ireland can reopen from July , it was announced this afternoon. The announcement came from Economy Minister Diane Dodds as the easing of the coronavirus lockdown continues. She said that the reopening was dependent on advice from medical experts about the spread of the virus. Hotels had originally been given an indicative date of July  for reopening but that date has now been brought forward. Self-catering tourist accommodation can open from June , added Mrs Dodds. Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council are to reallocate over pound, to run a direct marketing campaign to attract tourists back to the north coast. The measure is recommended in a report discussed at last nights meeting of the council’s Leisure and Development Committee. A total of pound, will be reallocated for the campaign, with pound, being spent on advertising and pound, on promotional activity through media and influencers. A further pound, will be set aside for website build cost, which will update the Visit Causeway and Glens website. The site has not been updated since . The campaign will focus on key targets for the Causeway Coastal Route, as identied by Tourism Northern Ireland and hopes to strengthen the council’s relationship with the organisation. googletag.cmd.push It is hoped this measure will assist the Tourism and Hospitality sector in the recovery of lost business, income and employment after the Covid- pandemic. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Members of the Helicopter Emergency Medical Serviceare taking part in an ambitious challenge this Autumn to raise funds for Air Ambulance Northern Ireland . The medics will attempt to cycle  miles in two days, beginning at the South Western Area Hospital and finishing at the Royal Victoria Hospital. A target of pound, has been set for the challenge, but the group are optimistic of hitting pound, – the cost of running the Air Ambulance for just two days. Dr Rory Maguire, HEMS Consultant and Anaesthetist at Belfast City Hospital, said the team hoped to offset some of the impact Covid- has had on fundraising efforts. googletag.cmd.push He said: “Our team are very aware of the impact of Covid- at the frontline, in our community and the impact on Air Ambulance NI income. “I have some experience in cycling, but this will be a completely dferent challenge as  of our team come together in a -mile physical challenge instead of our usual HEMS roles.” The event will begin on Friday, October  and finish in Belfast on Saturday, October , with the participants pledging to keep the public informed of their progress through regular vlogs. Kerry Anderson, Head of Fundraising at Air Ambulance NI said the task facing the HEMS medics is a steep one. googletag.cmd.push “We are extremely grateful to the HEMS team for what they do for patients every day and now in taking on this challenge to help raise vital funds for the charity,” she said. “Many of the team are taking on cycling for the first time so we know this won’t be easy and we wish them every success over the coming weeks and months.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Derry is to host a major online learning festival. Derry City and Strabane District Council have revealed a packed programme for the Virtual LearningFestival, which will take place on July st and nd. Marking the citys membership of the UNESCOS Global Network of Learning Cities, the festival – which is funded by the council, North West Regional College and Ulster University - will offer a wide range of online learning experiences and activities. title: ‘Get off our land’ plea after trespassers cause anguish
story: FARMERS in the Saul area outside Downpatrick have issued an impassioned plea to trespassers mdash get off our land.The farmers say they have been bedevilled by trespassers for years and are now totally fed up.In the latest incident a gate was left open and cattle were able to get into a nearby barley field, causing substantial damage to the valuable crop.In other incidents fields have been strewn with rubbish, while dog faeces, which is potentially harmful to cattle, has been found in a field used for making silage.The farmers have enlisted the support of South Down MLA Colin McGrath, who has issued an appeal for respect of local farmland and for walkers to refrain from trespassing.One farmer is considering installing expensive CCTV equipment in an attempt to identy trespassers.The farmer said that after years of many incidents the most recent event was the ldquostraw that broke the camelrsquos back.ldquoSomeone rang me to say the they had seen the cattle running and a walker had been seen over the land, the farmer remarked.ldquoThis person must have left the gate open to the neighbouring field because at .pm that night I got a call to say that the cattle were running over the barley field.ldquoTwo hours later we got the cattle out, but the barley had just been sprayed with a fungicide, so I am hoping that there is no long term damage done to the cattlethey had digested it. There was substantial damage done to the crop.The farmer continued: ldquoI also had a man who was purposely letting his dog into a field to go to the toilet every morning. This field is used to cut silage for the animals to eat in winter. What these people donrsquot understand is that dog faeces is potentially harmful to cattle.ldquoI appreciate that people like to go for a walk and it is unprecedented times where people are more cautious about meeting people on the roads, but they canrsquot use farmland as recreational ground.ldquoThat is a farmerrsquos work space and every blade of grass is used in farming, eventhere areno cows in the field that they are walking in. The ground is being used for something, be it winter fodder or rotational grazing.ldquoThere are cows calving in my fields and what I am more worried about is that someone is going to get hurt. Cows are extremely volatile around calving season and they will attackthey think their young are in danger.ldquoThe most dangerous animal on a farm is not a bull, itrsquos a newly calved cow. They can and will kill. People think that cows are docile but they can kill.The farmer added: ldquoI am having to look into getting professional CCTV equipment put in place over the land, an expense I could really do without.Mr McGrath said people walking through gated fields, leaving the gates lying open and allowing the livestock to get out placed an ldquounnecessary burden on farmers.ldquoWith some Covid- restrictions being eased itrsquos great to see that people are able to get out and about a bit more whether that be for walking their dogs, going for a longer walk or run or just getting out and about. We need to make full use of our wonderful natural surroundings for our own health and for our own emotional and psychological wellbeing.ldquoHowever, there are issues creeping in regarding walkers and runners using gated fields and pieces of farmland as access points whether for a shortcut or just because they feel they can do this.He continued: ldquoWhen I was growing up in Downpatrick you didnrsquot dare trespass on the land. There was enough respect for the farmer and the great contribution they make to our local communities and as a child probably a healthy level of fear as well.ldquoI want our communities to respect our farmers and to appreciate that they give to the community so much more than they get back.ldquoSoyoursquore out and about and enjoying your walks or runs, please stick to the public roads and public rights of way..prettyPhoto

title: A walk in the pairc
story: LOCAL GAA clubs are gearing up for ato action.After a three-month lockdown caused by the Covid- pandemic, clubs can look forward to a resumption of gaelic games.Thatrsquos good news for players and spectators, who have been starved of action.The clubs were able to unlock their gates for the first time this week.From Monday they were allowed to open their grounds for small groups of people to use walkways.Non-contact training for club teams will begin on June , initially in groups of no more than ten players with two coaches.Full-contact training can take place from July , with underage games commencing on the same date. Adult club games can begin on July .Inter-county competition is scheduled to start on October  with training likely to begin in September. That means the likelihood of All-Ireland championships running into .The schedule is set out on the GAArsquos Safe Return to Gaelic Games road map which was announced last Friday.Down GAA has yet to announce its plans for the coming months, but it seems likely that there will be a curtailed programme in the county.County officials have been meeting to formulate arrangements, which will have be sanctioned by the Down County Board, after which clubs will be informed.It is not knownthe all county leagues will be played. However, it seems likely that championships will take place.A Down GAA spokesman said: ldquoWe will have a window of opportunity to play club championships and the CCC have been engaged in preparing for any possibleto play.ldquoAto play will bring with it a dferent set of challenges to what we have ever been used to and in the public interest we must embrace the challenges and regulations set before us to ensure the health and well-being of our members, their families and their friends.ldquoIt will be dferent, but by adhering to what we need to do we will have the opportunity to play games in the summer and autumn of .The spokesman said clubs were not permitted to train on council facilities or farmersrsquo land.The spokesman added: ldquoIn the interim we again remind our clubs to adhere to the regulations at present until the agreed dates as outlined.The spokesman had this message for clubs and players: ldquoBe patient and follow theto play protocol..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch homes plan gets green light
story: PLANS for a major private housing development on the outskirts of Ballynahinch have secured formal planning approval.Members of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee last week formally signed off a proposal to build  homes at an  acre site on land between  and  Lisburn Road.Last weekrsquos meeting was the first Planning Committee session to take place since the local authority cancelled all its statutory meetings in response to the coronavirus.The development, which includes a range of detached, semi-detached and townhouses, is close to the Lime Trees, Edengrove and Kinedale housing developments.Planners have confirmed that the proposed site is within Ballynahinchrsquos development limits and while plans were initially lodged to build  homes, the figure was subsequently revised to .The Department for Infrastructure is content that the proposed housing scheme can be accommodated within the existing roads network, while Northern Ireland Water said there is available capacity within the existing sewerage system to cope with the planned new homes and that planning permission has been granted for a new sewage pumping station on adjacent land.A number of objections were lodged in opposition to the housing proposal in relation to traffic and access arrangements, claims that the application had not been properly advertised and insufficient neighbourhood notication.However, planners were content that the scheme could proceed with their recommendation endorsed by local politicians.Planners say the proposed development is ldquoappropriate to the character and topography of the site and that ldquoadequate provision is made for public and private open space and landscaped areas as an integral part of the development.They also said that the new development would not have an ldquounacceptable, adverse effect on existing or proposed properties in terms of overlooking, loss of light, overshadowing, noise or other disturbance..prettyPhoto

title: Beleaguered tourism sector needs boost
story: RADICAL steps need to be taken to boost Northern Irelandrsquos beleaguered tourism and hospitality businesses in order to aid their recovery from the Covid- pandemic, according to Baroness Margaret Ritchie.Speaking in the House of Lords last week, she said the abolition of air passenger duty and a reduction in VAT would help preserve jobs and provide a much-needed economic boost.Spending on tourism in Northern Ireland amounted to a massive pound billion last year. The industry directly employs , people, with thousands more supported in work through the supply chain.The impact of the virus on the sector could be devastating, Baroness Ritchie told peers during a debate on measures needed to repair the UK economy.ldquoProjections indicate that this level of employment could be reduced by  per cent, she said. ldquoThere has been no spend in the tourism industry since March  and it will be late July before tourism outlets open.ldquoMany of those people who will find themselves out of work will have to rely on the benefit system which is already under extreme pressure. It is punitive and needs to be overhauled with the needs of people put at the centre of the debate.She continued: ldquoTo encourage visitors to come to our region to spend money and to invest in our economy, we need to protect our people.ldquoThat means we must ensure our shops are allowed to open subject to social distancing rules and the British Government needs to abolish air passenger duty and reduce VAT on tourism.ldquoThat would assist our hospitality industry and those employed in it as well as the many people who depend on it for their basic source of income. These fiscal measures could indirectly make contributions to reducing inequalities in our society and community. Baroness Ritchie said the furloughing of many staff within the hospitality sector was currently concealing the true extent of the job losses that would follow when the scheme was ended.She also said the pandemic had revealed the ldquodeep levels of poverty and inequalities that are entrenched within many communities.She went on: ldquoThere have been greater levels of dependence on food banks for essential food provisions. Many people are now out of work through furloughing ndash some of them might not there are redundancies as a result of a deep recession.ldquoMany businesses will find it dficult to survive. This impacts on our society and economy and can cause isions within our society to deepen. There will be a greater reliance on benefits.She added: ldquoNew economic and social affairs strategies need to emerge following the pandemic, and they must demonstrate that efforts are being made to address those inequalities.ldquoOpportunities need to be taken to reframe the welfare debate and ensure that the cap on benefits is removed..prettyPhoto

title: Call for restoration of full services at Downe
story: THERE have been calls for the reinstatement of services at the Downe Hospital.Baroness Margaret Ritchie and Alliance councillor Patrick Brown are both demanding the full restoration of services which were removed at the height of the Covid- pandemic.Baroness Ritchie says she has pressed health chiefs on the issue, but to date has not been given a timeline by the South Eastern Trust.ldquoIt is important that the work on the reinstatement of services and staff continues and that the timeline for doing so is published so that the public is fully aware of all the circumstances, she said.ldquoUndoubtedly, all the staff in the Downe Hospital, including medical, nursing and ancillary, have worked with very dficult challenges over the last few months and they deserve our support, solidarity and congratulations.Baroness Ritchie said she had been told equipment will be ed to the Downe and that the Trust was progressing plans for the rebuilding of non-Covid health and social care services.She said she had pressed senior management on the provision of endoscopy services at the Downe and was informed that the service recommenced in the day procedure unit on June .She said  patients were examined during the first session and that the Trust currently had  patients on their lsquored flag escalation listrsquo for endoscopy services.She said priority was being given to those with higher risk of cancer at this stage. ldquoThese patients are getting access to urgent endoscopy usually within the three-week target, she remarked.She added: ldquoIn response to my query about the scoping work for additional services to be provided at the Downe Hospital, the Trust has informed me that planning for the provision of services to be delivered from the day procedure Unit at the Downe Hospital is part of the overall work the Trust is progressing in relation to the rebuilding of non-Covid  health and social services.ldquoIt is also anticipated that other day case surgical work will recommence shortly afterwards.Cllr Brown called on the Trust to reconsider its decision to engage with a private firm to offer endoscopy treatment at the Downe and to reinstate the AE department, as well as investing in what he said were ldquomuch-needed services for the local community.He claimed privatising healthcare put limits on those who could receive treatment.ldquoOur constituents should have access to high quality local services, he said.ldquoWhilst the dficult and unprecedented circumstances caused by the Covid- pandemic have undoubtedly added a strain on hospital resources, the decision to involve a private contractor for endoscopy treatments should be swtly reconsidered.ldquoInstead, efforts should be made to find a cohesive solution with current medical staff and relevant unions, in order to safeguard our local services.He continued: ldquoThe decision to close the AE Department in Downe Hospital was taken to reallocate resources and staff to other hospitals to help fight Covid-, especially at the peak of the virus.ldquoWhilst it is understandable that medical services needed to adapt as a response to the outbreak, Downe Hospital failed to have a sufficient offering in terms of emergency medical care prior to the pandemic, with an AE Department that only operated for  hours of the day.Cllr Brown said a global health crisis should not be used as an excuse to remove or rationalise health services.He remarked: ldquoDowne Hospital is a vital local employer and necessary for the health and wellbeing of residents across the District.ldquoLocal rural constituents should not have to worry that they wonrsquot have adequate access to healthcare, as services have been displaced to Belfast or Dundonald.ldquoThere is a clear need to invest in services, restoring those lost and making Downe Hospital a centre of excellence for a iety of treatments, mental and physical..prettyPhoto

title: Cyclists saddle up to raise £66k for Downpatrick charity
story: A GROUP of cyclists spent a week in the saddle to raise money for a local charity recently.Thirteen cyclists completed a week-long charity ride to raise funds for Mainstay DRP Day Care Centre in Downpatrick.The event was planned by a member of the Mainstay DRP committee and cyclists ranged from novices to experienced cyclists who usually ride once or twice a week.Some cyclists used mountain bikes, others rode racing bikes and one rider, who is self-isolating,completed his miles on a turbo trainer at home.Participants were aged from -plus to -plus and their aim was to complete a total of , miles in a week, riding as iniduals to adhere to the social distancing rules.The , mile mark was achieved by the end of day three, with everyone pushing themselves to the limit. Motivated by the cumulative mileage achieved so quickly, and despite the very windy, stormy conditions during the last few days, the riders went on to complete an amazing , miles.Donations raised over pound, for Mainstay DRP Day Care Centre at Cumulus Heights, Downpatrick.Mainstay DRP supports adults with learning disabilities and or autism through the provision of daycare opportunities, residential and respite care and supported housing.The money will be used to purchase a kiln and a poly-tunnel, with surplus funds used to further enhance day care resources.For more information or to make a donation go to see Mainstaydrp or justgiving mainstay..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick defy North Down and the weather to secure cup
story: ON September , , Downpatrick beat North Down by six wickets to win the Irish Senior Cup.The match was played at Downpatrickrsquos Strangford Road ground and continued the Northern domination of the competition.Cricket, though, wasnrsquot to the forefront of the Linehan family, which provided three members of the side.Paul Linehan, son of Hugh and nephew of Alfie, recalled: ldquo was a terribly wet summer. Crops lay flat in the fields from the constant pounding of the rain. As a family of farmers it was an extremely dficult time.ldquoIn between the deluges we managed to scramble our way to the first Irish Senior Cup final and emerged victorious mdash a rare moment of sunshine that year.For Paul, then a teenager still at school, the memories of  years ago are still vivid.ldquoIt was my first year in the st XI, playing alongside my father and Alfie. They were  and  years young at that time and still playing well.ldquoIn fact, the following year, in the same competition, I sat in amazement watching Alfie blast a ton against a Bangor with John Elder leading the attack, having opened the bowling for Ireland against Australia earlier that summer in front of , people at Downpatrick.ldquoAnyway, Alfie smashed nine huge sixes, all clearing the Strangford Road end. This was at a spritely age of .ldquoAll of a sudden I realised the legendary tales of Alfiersquos big hitting were true. Dad always said he hit the ball much further than anyone . That innings remains the most memorable I have seen from a Downpatrick player. saw the ICU as it was then bring in bowl-outs to decide washed-out contests, with all  players trying to hit the stumps in a shoot-out.In the first round Downpatrick faced Leinster and of the  players who aimed, only one was successful mdash the aforementioned Alfie.Downpatrick had reached the final after a famous win in the lionrsquos den of Donemana, with Brian Ferris and Jim Patterson smashing unbeaten fties in an emphatic victory.ldquoThere was a lot of publicity surrounding the Irish Senior Cup which at that time was sponsored by Schweppes, said Paul.ldquoIn the years that followed, just like the inter-pros played for the Guinness Cup, everyone simply called the competition lsquoThe Schweppesrsquo. In more recent times, the Ulster Cup was known as lsquoThe Clubturfrsquo.ldquoBefore the final, BBC TV sent a crew down to interview some of us, and ironically record us bowling at the stumps. It was still raining. It took us ages to hit the stumpshellipI got abuse at school.ldquoNeedless to say, the final was washed out without a bowl bowled and the miserable summer continued. It was desperately disappointing after a week of huge anticipation.The toss for the venue of the replay was conducted over the phone between the two captains, Ian Shields and Derek McCann.Downpatrick won and the replay was scheduled for midweek, Wednesday, September , and North Downrsquos Robin Haire recalls the conditions werenrsquot really fit for cricket.ldquoDownpatrick had actual puddles of water on parts of outfield, he recalled. ldquoMy abiding memory of that final was the spray of the water when you hit it along the ground.ldquoIt was totally unplayable, but the authorities wanted it played and out of the way. Nowadays umpires would have said try tomorrow.The decider itself proved to be a turgid, low-key affair, with little atmosphere and a contest which matched the gloomy conditions.ldquoIt just felt like a midweek league game, said Paul Linehan. ldquoPeople were at work, there was no crowd to speak of, it was cold and it wasnrsquot much of a game.ldquoNorth Down batted first, we bowled and fielded brilliantly, and they scraped to just . Karl Quinn and man of the match Philip Lennon each took three wickets, Jim Patterson got two, while Brian Hodges and Brian Ferris got one apiece.ldquoWe opened with Keith Malone and Derek McCann and I was due to come in three. I was a very nervous  year-old when I arrived at the wicket after they had put on . Keith was going well and I just needed to stay in.ldquoAnyway, desperate to get off the mark, I predicted Robin Haire was going to bowl me a long hop. I was right back on the stumps, ready to smash it, when he fired in a quicker ball which crashed into my ankles in front of middle. Out for a duck in the All-Ireland Cup final. I was beyond devastated as cricket was everything to me.ldquoWe eventually won by six wickets as our experienced side adopted a safety-first attitude, taking no risks. Derek McCann lted the famous trophy and Downpatrick were All-Ireland champions.There were to be no champagne celebrations for the teenager though.ldquoUnfortunately, I was too young to down a couple of beers, so it was straight back home after the final for Dad and I, two All-Ireland champions.Six years later, Downpatrick would secure the trophy for the second time in one of the most thrilling encounters ever, overcoming North by three runs.There was to be no personal glory though for Paul Linehan as he missed out on the chance of redemption.ldquoThe disappointment of making a duck remains as I was never to play in another All-Ireland final, having been injured for the  victory, he said.ldquoHowever, all these years later, my  medal is still very much a prized possession..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C June 10%2C 2000
story: TYRELLA mdash Tyrella beach has retained a prestigious European award which recognises the quality of the local tourist facility.The beach is one of eight in the province to receive the highly sought after Blue Flag Award, the highest possible recognition for cleanliness.Down Council chiefs are delighted Tyrella has once again been recognised for its quality, and the amount of effort they put into maintaining it, in the annual Tidy Britain Group awards.The awards were officially handed over on Monday along with the prestigious Blue Flag which will continue to fly high over Tyrella for the next  months.The beach was rigorously examined in an unannounced inspection by a  of European experts who focused their attention on cleanliness and the environmental management of Tyrella.Council official Leonard Lawson said everyone was delighted their efforts have again been recognised.ldquoThe award also recognises the councilrsquos effort to manage the beach, provide information points, educational material and detailed displays in the beach centre, he said.ldquoThe water quality is also critical to ensure Blue Flag status is retailed and the council aims to continue to work hard to maintain its high standards.NEWCASTLE mdash Armed robbers made off with over pound, in cash yesterday morning after a hold-up at a Newcastle bank.The three masked men burst into the Northern Bank in Main Street at .am and order everyone inside to co-operate. One produced a handgun and pointed it at staff members while the other two went behind the counter and lted money from the cash drawers.They made off in a black Ford Escort, which police found abandoned at the Royal County Down Golf Club just minutes after the robbery. It had been stolen from the public car park of the Newcastle Centre a before the hold-up.Nobody was injured in the incident but, according to a police spokesperson, employees and customers were left in a state of stock.ldquoThere was pandemonium and a lot of shouting and yelling,rsquorsquo he said. ldquoPolice were in the area at the time and managed to locate the getaway car within minutes of the robbery. When they got to the vehicle, the engine was still running but there was nobody in sight.Extensive searches were carried out and police are appealing for anyone with information about the movements of the iniduals involved and the cars used in the hold-up.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh residents who are battling to have the townrsquos former high school reopened, are to meet shortly with education chiefs.They believe the talks with chief executive of the South Eastern Education and Library Board, Mr Jackie Fitzsimons, mark another signicant step in their campaign to have the doors of the school reopened to students.Mr Fitzsimons has confirmed he is prepared to meet representatives from the Friends of Killyleagh High School with the meeting due to take place within the next few weeks.Senior politicians including Strangford MP John Taylor, Assembly members and local councillors are all backing the campaign and believe that with other schools in the secondary sector heavily over subscribed Killyleagh High must be reopened.Over , people have signed a petition calling for the school to be opened and the group behind the campaign says the results of a questionnaire it launched last year ldquoprove beyond doubt there are enough students to ensure the reopening is viable.rsquorsquoLocal community worker Billy Walker said the results of the recent questionnaire provided what he described as ldquooverwhelming evidence of the need for additional secondary school places in the area.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Detectives investigating a shooting incident in Ballynahinch last week have issued an appeal for information.They want to hear from anyone who was in the Langley Road estate on Tuesday night and saw anyone acting suspiciously.A local man who was shot had to be taken to the Downe Hospital in Downpatrick where he was treated for his injuries before being released. It is understood the shooting is linked to a family feud in the area.Superintendent Brendan McGuigan, the local police chief, confirmed yesterday that while a number of people had been arrested in connection with the incident, no one had been charged.STRANGFORD mdash A replacement vessel is expected to be in operation on the Strangford ferry route by late .The new ferry will replace the MV Portaferry at a cost of pound million, creating a more up to date and efficient service on the busy route.But, according to the Roads Service Divisional Manager, Mr Jim Price, fares are likely to increase with the introduction of the modernised service.ldquoThe Roads Service already spends pound, a year subsidising current fares and this is unlikely to go away,rsquorsquo he said.BALLYHORNAN mdash South Down MP Eddie McGrady has welcomed a commitment by the Housing Executive to rehabilitating a Ballyhornan housing complex.According to Mr McGrady, the dwellings at Ben Derg Park require external and internal improvements.The improvement scheme is scheduled to begin in , but the local politician has vowed to continue to lobby for an earlier start date.Among the improvements to be carried out by the Housing Executive are the upgrading of heating systems, the repair-refurbishment of kitchens and bathrooms and the improvement of space standards to both bungalows and houses.DRUMANESS mdash Roads Service officials have been warned to ensure the provision of a new footpath at a dangerous junction in Drumaness is top of their priority list.The warning has been issued by local councillor Anne McAleenan who has been waging a lone crusade to have a path provided at the junction of the Old Park Road and Crawfordstown Road.Despite promises by Roads Service officials that the work will be carried out, Mrs McAleenan says she is still waiting and her patience is beginning to run out.SAINTFIELD mdash Saintfield is bracing itself for a show-stopping spectacular millennium festival.The action kicks off this Friday and the nine-day extravaganza ends with one of the major events on the provincersquos agriculture calendar, Saintfield Show.Organisers aim to provide people with a spectacle they will not forget in a hurry and promise the many events will highlight everything that is good about the area.In addition to providing a fun-filled festival, the organisers also aim to raise lots of money for charity and with the final touches being put to all the events this week.Organisers say the emphasis throughout the cross-community festival is having fun and turning the spotlight on a town which is rapidly expanding at the start of the new millennium.SPA mdash Clues about the lestyle of Downrsquos first inhabitants have been uncovered near Spa in one of the most signicant archaeological finds in the country.The first ever Neolithic home to be uncovered in County Down has been found at Dunmore Mountain, giving an insight into the community that lived in this area up to , years ago.It was uncovered by a team of archaeologists working on the Aquarius Mourne Water Project, a major pipeline development between Newcastle and Belfast.Fragments of pottery and flint tools are among the find, which experts say offer the only clues about the lives of those who lived locally from ,BC to ,BC..prettyPhoto

title: Late Coulter strike sends Down into Ulster semis
story: After a number of years in the doldrums Downrsquos footballing fortunes took a dramatic upturn in  when they reached the All-Ireland final. The journey to Croke Park began against DonegalDonegal -Down -ULSTER SFC QUARTER-FINALBENNY Coulter popped up late in extra-time to send Down soaring through to the semi-finals of the Ulster SFC with a magical goal to break Donegalrsquos hearts in Ballybofey on Sunday.Coulter, the undoubted man of the match, struck gold when he got on the end of a sweeping move involving Danny Hughes and Martin Clarke to secure a clash with Tyrone.Both sides started tentatively and Down midfielder Kalum King was yellow carded after five minutes, but Donegalrsquos Dermot Molloy escaped punishment after he clashed with Damian Rafferty.Molloy opened the scoring in the eighth minute with a point from play before both Mark Poland and John Clarke registered wides for Down.Donegal then hit Down for six when Molloy took advantage of some poor defensive play and lashed the ball past a helpless Brendan McVeigh.Down were up against it, but their nerves were settled when Coulter and Clarke pointed to leave Donegal with a - to - lead after  minutes.Poland converted a free to leave a point in it, but Donegal must have thought Christmas had come early when they bagged a second goal when Molloyrsquos shot came off the upright and Conal Dunne was on hand to steer the ball into the net in the th minute.Martin Clarke answered Downrsquos call with a point and this was followed up by a similar score from Hughes as Down trailed - to - after  minutes.Coulter had a good effort well saved by Paul Durcan before Molloy extended Donegalrsquos lead with a long range free. With  minutes gone Poland pointed for Down, but the impressive Molloy negated this score with a point for Donegal.The half closed with Hughes pointing for Down in the second minute of stoppage time with just two points between the sides at the break.Donegal opened the scoring in the second half when Michael Murphy converted a free, but Poland replied for Down with another converted free.Adrian Hanlon, who had replaced Christy Toye, tagged on a point for Donegal to give his side a - to - lead with  minutes left, but Hughes reduced the arrears with a superb point for Down.Marty Clarke left a point in it with a lovely score and Coulter fired over the equalising point in the th minute after good foraging by Benny McArdle.David Walsh fisted Donegal back ahead, but Durcan saved Donegalrsquos bacon at the other end when he twice denied Dan Gordon, who was now operating at full forward.Coulter, who had moved out the field, then fired over the score of the game to bring the sides level with only two minutes remaining and Marty Clarke lofted Down ahead for the first time in the game with only seconds remaining.Donegal had Rory Kavanagh to thank for sending the game to extra time when he pointed with the last kick of the game to make it - to .Coulter scored the first point in extra time and this was followed up by a score from Hughes as Down started to dictate matters.The first period of added time ended with Down two points ahead, - to -.Mark McHugh reduced the arrears within seconds of the restart Colm McFadden brought the sides level at - to -.The game was there for the taking and Coulter was perfectly placed to accept Marty Clarkersquos pass before firing to the net in a dramatic late twist.Eoin Wade replied with an instant Donegal point, but Down held out for an epic victory.Down: B. McVeigh, B. McArdle, D. Rooney, D. Rafferty, K. McKernan, J.Colgan, C. Garvey, D. Gordon, K. King, D. Hughes , M. Poland , P. McComiskey, B. Coulter , J. Clarke , M. Clarke . Subs: C. Maginn for J.
