McHughfor Gallagher, C. McFaddenfor D. Molloy, E. Wadefor Maguire..prettyPhoto

title: Mr Joseph McMcIlmail
story: MR Joseph McIlmail, of Crew Road, Downpatrick, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, April , at the age of .Joe, as he was known to his family and many friends, was the fourth child of the late John Joe and Margaret McIlmail, from Bright. He was a loving brother to Margaret , Eileen , Jimmy, Mary and the late John.At the age of  he left school and started his apprenticeship as a carpenter joiner at Ballykinlar Camp for Sintons. After serving his time, he went to work in England in the early s, ing for a period when he met his we Sylvia, who he married in .The couple moved to Coventry where Joe continued to work for a few years. They ed to Downpatrick where Joe worked for several well-known local building firms, including Casements, Hugh J OrsquoBoyle and Taggarts, before he commenced his own building firm. Joe was a perfectionist with a great eye for detail and took pride in all the work he undertook.Joe had several hobbies. He loved photography and never went anywhere without a camera to capture the moment. He took the official photographs for several weddings, but ever the perfectionist he always worried how they would turn out until they were developed mdash unlike in todayrsquos digital age.Many of his interests were connected to the sea and the coast. He enjoyed fishing and always owned a small boat to go on short fishing trips. He also loved joining friends from Strangford and Kilclief on trips to the Isle of Man.Sailing was another great passion, being a crew member on trips to the Scottish and Irish coast before getting his own yacht on which he and his we were the only crew.Joe loved being in company and valued friendship. He liked meeting up with friends and family and hearing as well as telling a good story. He often couldnrsquot finish his stories from laughing too much at the memory of what he was going to tell and his laughter was infectious.He is survived by Sylvia, sons Joe, Paul and Mark, daughters Margaret and Anne, grandsons Austin, Malachy, Joseph, Eoin, Brian and Jack, granddaughters Natasha and Aimee, great grandsons Callum and John, great granddaughters Scarlett-Grace, Amelia-Rose, Lily and Eva, the wider family circle, friends and neighbours. May he rest in peace..prettyPhoto

title: Planners give approval for latest phase at housing site
story: PLANNERS have given the green light for the latest phase of building work at the former Downe Hospital site in Downpatrick to proceed.Contractors were forced to abandon construction in March due to the coronavirus pandemic, but are now back building much-needed homes on behalf of Clanmil Housing.An initial  homes are being built part as part of the major social housing project at the sprawling site where around  new homes could eventually be constructed at a huge area which borders four main roads.The redevelopment of the former hospital site includes a range of housing types including apartments, two and three storey homes and bungalows.The former hospital and canteen building behind it mdash which are both listed buildings mdashhave been incorporated into the development plan as apartment blocks, with the development proposals for these formally approved this week.Planners have given the green light for  apartments and two semi-detached homes with construction work involving the partial demolition of the former hospital infirmary and administration buildings which will be extended to accommodate the proposed new-build.The planned development includes provision for open space, landscaping access and parking.Planning permission has also been granted for  new dwellings, comprising  homes and four apartments, on a pocket of land south of Pound Lane and west of John Street.It is understood that as part of the development of the entire site, the main entrance into the former hospital complex off Pound Lane will remain, while a new entrance is also proposed on the Ardglass Road side.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran said the work at the former hospital site will be ldquoinstrumental in helping address the need for more social homes in the town.In addition, he said that the construction of the new homes can assist with the social and economic regeneration of this particular area.ldquoThe redevelopment jigsaw is taking shape and it is great see new houses springing up from the ground at part of the town that was an eyesore after the old hospital closed in . It is hard to believe that it has taken  years to get to the stage we are at now at, but the sight of new homes going up is welcome, he continued.ldquoWhile the regeneration of this part of Downpatrick is vital, so is the impact the new homes project will have on addressing a critical shortage of social housing. Many of those in need of a new home are in the urgent need category and the sooner tenants can start to move in, the better.Cllr Curran explained that those in the urgent need category are the priority as far as housing providers are concerned.He also hopes that given the progress that is being made at the former hospital site that families may be able to move in before December.The councillor said the new social housing project will benefit the wider community by providing construction jobs and boosting buildersrsquo suppliers and hopes that those on the waiting list for homes in the town will be offered the new properties.He added: ldquoThis eagerly-awaited scheme is ridding Downpatrick of a derelict site which will be transformed to deliver modern homes in an area of high demand.Local SDLP MLA Colin McGrath also welcomed the plannersrsquo approval.He said: ldquoThe housing development at the old Downe site has been a protracted and drawn out process.ldquoHaving been in regular contact with Clanmil to see what were the outstanding issues holding this development back to hear that council planners are to approve the next stage of the development at long last is very welcome news.ldquoI look forward to seeing how this scheme progresses and how quickly we can get people into these developments.Mr McGrath added: Irsquom grateful for the engagement with Clanmil and look forward to continuing this into the future..prettyPhoto

title: Pompey dream
story: BALLYNAHINCH teenage soccer player Eoin Teggart has been given a massive career boost.The hugely talented  year-old has been offered a third year scholarship by Portsmouth.The Northern Ireland youth International joined the League One clubrsquos academy from Cltonville in September  and has blossomed ever since.He made his debut for the academyrsquos first team against Norwich City in the Leasing Trophy as helped set up two goals as Portsmouth reached the final against Salford City at Wembley Stadium.Academy manager Mark Kelly was full of praise for the youngster: ldquoEoin has got plenty of pace and crossing ability mdash now he just needs to hone in on a few things.He is one of three players to be offered third year scholarships by Portsmouth.Kelly added: ldquoThey all deserve this opportunity, but have to get their heads down and be ready to go again.The ultimate aim is to catch the attention of Portsmouth manager Kenny Jackett and secure a place in his first team squad.Before his move to Cltonville Teggart was part of a highly successful Ballynahinch United youth team that went unbeaten for two seasons in the South Belfast Youth League before spending some time at Ridgeway Rovers and Glentoran.He was also part of the County Down side that reached the SuperCupNI Premier final in .On the local soccer front meanwhile, Billy Heal has been appointed as the new first team manager at Dundrum United.Heal was unveiled at the weekend by club chairman Jim McIlwrath and Chris Hogg, vice-chairman and club captain.He takes over from Andy Smyth who will continue with the club as a player and committee member.For over  years Heal has been involved with football within South Down, starting off with the Valley Youth.For the last three seasons he was first team manager at Ballyvea, who led to a double in the Newcastle League.He then took Ballyvea into the Mid Ulster League where they gained promotion at the first time of asking, finishing runners-up to Annalong, and reached the final of the Foster Cup, which has still has to be played because of the coronavirus lockdown.A spokesman for Dundrum United said Healrsquos appointment had the committeersquos overwhelming support and that it was first time a person from outside the club had been appointed as manager.The spokesman said the the club was aiming for a top three finish in the league and winning at least one cup.ldquoBillyrsquos aspirations with Dundrum United are to install a winning mentality and a hard working ethos within the club with fitnesses his driving force..prettyPhoto

title: Report to be published on future of Ardglass harbour
story: DETAILS of a new initiative aimed at revitalising Ardglass harbour are expected to be published before the end of the month.Stormont fisheries minister Edwin Poots is due to unveil the first stage of a report from the Fishing and Seafood Development programme whichwill include a timeline for work that needs to be done at Ardglass and the other Co Down ports of Kilkeel and Portavogie.Earlier this year, Mr Poots met with South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran to discuss the future of the village port.They highlighted the importance of the Ardglass fishing industry to the district and wider South Down economy and outlined planned improvement work at the harbour, including deepening it to facilitate larger herring and mackerel vessels.Mr McGrath and Cllr Curran emphasised the need for additional investment in the harbour and its infrastructure, insisting that the port receives its fair share of funding to help enhance the existing fleet.They said that the harbour was ldquostrategically important for the Co Down fleet, highlighting its crucial role in driving the South Down economy and its location as a central hub for processing fish landed in Ardglass.The politicians said additional investment is critical to allow Ardglass harbour to expand with appropriate slipways provided for larger vessels to dock safely.Several weeks after the meeting with Mr Poots it was revealed that ambitious plans to redevelop Ardglass harbour could cost in the region of poundm.The figure is contained in a detailed consultants report commissioned to undertake an in-depth feasibility study to look at potential developments for the harbour which is home to Northern Irelandrsquos third largest fishing fleet.The key issue the consultants focused on was deepening the harbour to facilitate larger vessels, with work also undertaken to look at improving harbour conditions, berthing pontoons for smaller vessels and increased berthing facilities.In addition, the study included a comprehensive review of possible harbour layouts, historic document research, topographic and bathymetric harbour surveys, quay wall inspection above and below the waterline and computer modelling.The consultants also liaised with the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswhich has been given a copy of the consultants report ahead of further discussions with its officials on the way forward.Ardglass has the only all-weather harbour between Howth and Bangor and has three primary areas including the so-called fish dock within the south pier.Last August, ious concept layouts produced by consultants were reviewed by members of the Ardglass Harbour Developments group which has been set up to oversee the regeneration of the port. The concepts were subsequently amended in November.The prime focus is on deepening the harbour and moving forward, a cost effective approach may be to zone dredge levels in particular areas.Cllr Curran, who is keen to hear what Mr Poots has to say in a few weeksrsquo time, said there were plans to deepen the outer harbour by nine metres and the area adjacent to Cochranersquos building at the inner harbour by two metres to facilitate crab vessels.He confirmed that consideration is also being given to creating a pontoon with finger berths adjacent to the quay wall in front of Cochranersquos with gangway access for crab vessels. No leisure craft would be permitted at this part of the harbour.ldquoNew investment in Ardglass harbour can help sustain existing jobs and create new employment opportunities, said Cllr Curran. ldquoThe port plays a ket part in the local economy and is at the heart of village le.ldquoArdglass lands some of the largest quantities of prawns in Ireland and deepening the harbour will mean that larger fishing vessels that currently dock where, will be able to access local facilities.Cllr Curran also fears that not deepening the harbour could potentially lead to an economic collapse for the Ardglass fishing industry.He added: ldquoI look forward to hear what the fisheries minister has to say towards the end of the month and hope that it will be positively good news for Ardglass..prettyPhoto

title: Roadworks causing delays in town centre
story: A DOWNPATRICK businesswoman has called on Phoenix Gas to complete pipe laying work in St Patrickrsquos Avenue by next Monday mdash as promised.The company is investing poundm investment across East Down and to date has laid over  miles of natural gas pipeline, with contractors also currently working in Newcastle.Phoenix officials have been working with the Department for Infrastructure to identy areas where pipe-laying could be brought forward to avoid further disruption to traders, visitors and residents, with work in Downpatrick starting several weeks ago.A mains pipeline has already been laid in a number of areas in the town, with contractors recently completing work in the Edward Street area. Contractors then moved to Pound Lane and are now in St Patrickrsquos Avenue.Eleanor Telford, who owns Telrsquos Confectionary with her husband Alan, said that she believed that the pipe-laying would start outside her shop imminently.ldquoI suppose the work has to be done sometime and perhaps itrsquos better done now when things are still quiet, but I hope the work is completed within the time we have been told, she said.Motorists have faced some delays in St Patrickrsquos Avenue which feeds into Market Street, the townrsquos main shopping area.Phoenix hopes that by expediting its multi-million pound investment programme now, it will avoid further disruption later in the year, while also providing consumers with additional access to fuel choice before the winter period.The company insists that the safety of its staff and communities is of paramount importance, with the current pipe-laying work scheduled following ldquorobust risk assessment and the implementation of additional operational procedures, in line with government guidance.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran also appealed to Phoenix to complete the work as quickly as possible and for road users to remain patient during the work in the town centre which he said will result in inconvenience.He said it was always anticipated the work on such a major investment in towns and villages across the district would result in some degree of disruption and inconvenience.Cllr Curran said that the arrival of natural gas provides consumers with an added element of choice when it comes to their heating needs and said the investment in Downpatrick and right across the district opens up new opportunities to thousands of homeowners and the townrsquos business community.ldquoPipe-laying on such a large scale along congested streets and town centres results in disruption and while issues have arisen in the past, Phoenix has always done it best to minimise disruption, he said.ldquoBringing forward the work in Downpatrick, especially as schools across the town are closed as part of the coronavirus lockdown measures, makes sense. However, there will be concern about this project across the business community..prettyPhoto

title: Sam helping lift spirits with nursing home gigs
story: A KILLYLEAGH musician is lting the spirits of residents at a local nursing home mdash despite the Coronavirus lockdown and heart surgery.For over  years Sam Miskelly has been entertaining the residents of Fishbourne House at Spa, with his accordion.However, his weekly visits were put on hold after he underwent heart surgery several months ago and had stents fitted.He recovered only for the Covid- virus to spread around the globe, which meant he was no longer to go inside the home.Undaunted, the  year-old former lorry driver now sets up his accordion, amplier and microphone in the garden of the nursing home and residents are still able to enjoy his tuneful medleys.Sam is a regular performer at old tyme dances at a number of local venues and it was at one of them where he met Mr William Brown, owner of Fishbourne House.ldquoOne night he asked meI would play music for the residents. Thatrsquos how I came to play at the care home, he explained.ldquoI just love going there. The residents love to hear music that reminds them of the old days.Before his operation, he played in ious church and community halls, but he always ensured that Monday evenings were set aside for the residents of Fishbourne House.Sam likes to play a mixture of music, including country and gospel, as well as some Elvis Presley hits.He first picked up an accordion when he was  and has been playing it since.ldquoIrsquove never been able to read music. Instead I recall every note from memory and Irsquove built up quite a repertoire, he said.Around  Sam gave up driving lorries to concentrate on the music scene full time and he has gone on to acquire a faithful following.He performed regularly at afternoon tea dances and music evenings at Raa Orange Hall, Ballygowan Village Hall and Comber Unitarian Church Hall until the coronavirus pandemic took hold.Sam and his we, Avril, who have been married for  years, have two children, Stuartand Christine , and four grandsons, Jamieand Harryand two granddaughters, Katieand Aoe .It was only when Sam celebrated his th birthday last year that the couple realised their daughter, Christine, could be following in her dadrsquos musical footsteps.During the birthday celebrations Christine got up on stage and sang the Doris Day song, What Ever Will Be Will Be.ldquoThere wasnrsquot a dry eye in the hall that evening, Sam recalled. ldquoIt was the first time we both learned that the entertainment gene wasnrsquot dormant in the younger generation.Instead of birthday presents everyone who attended the party in Killinchy Presbyterian Church Hall gave donations to the Helping Hands charity, which is closely associated with the Royal Belfast for Sick Children. A total of pound, was raised.ldquoThe charity helped my grandson, Harry, recover when he was admitted to the hospital as an emergency and placed on a ventilator for seven days in . He was just four years old at the time, Samuel explained.ldquoWe were so grateful to the team and wanted to give something back, so we arranged the evening.To his wersquos delight, Sam is using the lockdown to some gardening work which had been put on hold for some time.Their garden has never looked so good and now Sam and Avril enjoy relaxing outside during the warm evenings.Sam added: ldquoWe both really miss not having family and friends over to show them how nice the garden finally looks. We especially miss not seeing our grandchildren. That has been the hardest part of all.To find out more about Sam log on to www.sammymiskelly biography-page..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick Centre opening welcome boost for tourism
story: LOCAL politicians have welcomed the reopening of the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick which is hoping to cash in on people staying at home for their summer holidays.The international attraction mdash dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint mdash closed to the public as part of the lockdown measures introduced to combat the deadly coronavirus.And as the centre prepares for the expected visitor boom over the summer months, local politicians are delighted that people will soon be flowing through its doors again.Prior to the pandemic, the centre was in the process of implementing new measures to grow its business following a strategic review by Newry, Mourne and Down Council which saw the centre as being pivotal role in supporting other local tourist attractions.As a result, a new five star group of local attractions has been formed led by the visitor centre which includes the Down County Museum, Down Cathedral, Downpatrick Railway Museum and Down Arts Centre.South Down MLA Emma Rogan and councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Robert Burgess are hoping that the St Patrick Centre can benefit from a surge in visitor demand.Ms Rogan, who met recently with centre director Dr Tim Campbell, says she has every confidence that he and his staff are stepping up to the challenges they face as we look towards a lsquonew normalrsquo.She said Newry, Mourne and Down Council must also work with and support the requirements of tourism businesses to help them compete ldquoin the new world we are entering into.Cllr Hanlon said while the impact of Covid- has presented challenges for the local tourism sector, a crisis can give birth to opportunity.She believes there is an opportunity to reshape the tourism industry in a way which will bring opportunities to local communities and business and that visitors will play a critical role in helping the local economy over the coming months.ldquoThe St Patrick Centre is an excellent base for the proposed five-star model which will promote the heritage and attractions our area has to offer, suggested Cllr Hanlon.ldquoWith social distancing now the new normal, smaller groups are likely to seek out authentic experiences that allow the visitor to connect with the landscape and local communities.Cllr Hanlon said that she believes that rural areas can offer an alternative to built up city areas for breaks.Cllr Burgess, who described the visitor centre as a district facility, believes that the centre can make the most of people deciding to holiday at home this summer.ldquoTourism is what we do best in this part of the world and while this particular industry has been decimated by coronavirus, it will slowly start to rebuild, he continued.ldquoWith huge influxes of international visitors not going to happen, the time is right for people across the island of Ireland to visit our district and stop off at the St Patrick Centre and the many other historic and ecclesiastical locations that we are fortunate to have.Cllr Burgess said the visitor centre can draw people into the area and direct them on to many other attractions across the district.ldquoThe visitor centre is a key hub for the district and does a tremendous job. Like the staff who run the facility, I hope that the facility will benefit from a signicant uptake in lsquostaycationsrsquo this summer, he said.Cllr Burgess is also encouraging people across the district who have not yet made their way to the St Patrick Centre to do so during any free time they may have over the summer..prettyPhoto

title: Virtual charity Rock Down concert
story: AN evening of the best of local rock and pop will be hosted on Friday as the Rock Down virtual concert kicks off.Organised by three friends from the Downpatrick and Strangford area ndash Sean Wallace, Harry Deegan, and Patrick Buchanan ndash the event showcasing the best of local talent will raise much-needed funds for mental health charity, Downpatrick PIPS.Donations for the gig have already reached more than pound, and more is likely to come in after the event.Nine acts will perform mostly acoustic sets live via Facebook stream from their own homes or venues ndash suitably socially distanced ndash from pm to pm.Opening up the concert will be Nicky Brown from Ballynahinch and finishing it off will be The Overknights.Other local acts include the Just Adam Band, Petty Youth, The Renegades, Eamon and Charlie Hanlon, Steafan Hanvey and Kevin Young who has just finished off his debut album. Eamon and Steafan supported Sinead OrsquoConnor on her recent UK and Ireland tour.Circus performer Sideshow Ramon will be entertaining viewers during the interval with a selection of fire-eating and sword-swallowing performances.Patrick he and his friends had always intended to organise a live event in support of PIPS this summer but decided to run it as a virtual event due to the lockdown.He explained: ldquoWe are all music lovers and have been to gigs all our lives. We know a lot of bands and performers so it was easy enough to contact them and they were generous enough to say yes.ldquoDownpatrick PIPS is a cause we are all passionate about. Mental health problems, suicide and depression is blighting our society and the local work that PIPS does is invaluable.ldquoSupporting good mental health is vitally important and we need a service where people can talk to people when they are feeling down or depressed. PIPS are there to provide that support.The trio held a very successful fundraiser for Downpatrick PIPS, known as PIPS at the Pot, a night of music at the Lobster Pot in Strangford two years ago where pound, was raised.An impromptu jam session at Mullanrsquos Bar in Downpatrick raised a further pound,.Downpatrick PIPSrsquo co-ordinator Brenda McAteer praised the men for continuing to support the charityrsquos work and said that apart from raising funds, this event will act as a way of getting some people to think about their mental health and to ask for help.ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the support and the creativeness of people raising money for us during the lockdown, she said.ldquoWhile PIPS at the Pot was a fantastic fundraiser, the awareness of our work that came out of that was phenomenal. It really got people talking and our referrals took off.We had people who contacted us after seeing the video released afterwards or by simply talking about their mental health on the night or someone they had lost to suicide and had never opened up about it.:Brenda added: ldquoWith Fridayrsquos event being a virtual event, we are hoping that it will reach even more people.To view the concert, visit www.facebook groups rockdown and to donate go to www.gofundme f PIPS RockDown.prettyPhoto

title: relaxation restrictions announced
story: Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill said: ldquoToday we have been able to continue the forward momentum in our phased recovery plan. The scientic and medical advice to the Executive at this time is that we are in a position to move forward on a number of further relaxations.ldquoWe understand the pressing need to tackle the issue of isolation, which is particularly dficult for those in single-person households. So, from this weekend, those people living alone will be able to join with one other household and have contact with them indoors. We are actively reviewing the wider situation on indoor meetings with family and friends and will provide an update on that next week.ldquoIrsquom pleased that we have also agreed today to open up the housing market and permit house moves. This is particularly good news for those who have been living in unsuitable accommodation and families in temporary accommodation who will now be able to move into social homes that are waiting for them.ldquoThe issue of childcare is crucial in our recovery journey and our decision to permit the opening of church facilities and community halls for day care is an important step in addressing this key issue.ldquoI believe that the relaxations we are announcing today are a balance between the welfare, social, and emotional needs of our people, as well progress towards opening up our economy.Health Minister Robin Swann said: ldquoThe Coronavirus emergency has been the biggest test of our whole society in many years. In dealing with the immediate threat to public health, we had no choice but to impose restrictions that were not only dficult to live with, but were in themselves damaging to our wider economic, societal and personal wellbeing.ldquoThe Executive committed to keeping these restrictions under review and agreed that we would not keep restrictions in place longer than we need to. Today, based on the scientic evidence and medical advice on the prevalence of infection and the course of the epidemic, we have agreed to make some signicant relaxations to the restrictions that remain in place.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. one of his articles that such a progressive town as Penarth was without an operatic and dramatic society, writes Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Societypresident, Mary Gardner.The response to his outcry was quickly taken up and within three weeks the Penarth Operatic Society was formed.The Societyrsquos first production was Gilbert  Sullivanrsquos Iolanthe, played at The Hippodrome which later burnt down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse due to the covid- restrictions.It might be some time before restrictions are lted on groups being able to rehearse together, or audiences allowed back in theatres, meanwhile PODS members keep in touch s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE RNLI in Wales has reacted to the Welsh Governmentrsquos plans for easing lockdown with an important safety warning.The Governmentrsquos changes, from Monday, June , will limit people to staying local and not generally travel more than five miles to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading.People from two dferent households in the same local area will be permitted to meet up as long as they are outdoors, and they maintain strict social distancing.The lesaving charity has called for the public to stay safe.RNLI lesaving manager, Matt Crofts said: ldquoAfter a warm spring coupled with the easing of a lockdown which has seen many of us unable to visit our local beaches, we expect many people to be eager to hit the coast.ldquoThe changes to Government guidance does not mean our coasts are safe.ldquoThe dangers that have always been there remain.ldquoWe ask those who are local to beaches to continue to be aware of the inherent dangers.ldquoOur strong advice to the Welsh public, who are not local to a beach, is to follow the Welsh Government guidance to meet outdoors and exercise locally and not to travel to the coast.ldquoAir temperatures may be warming up but the sea temperature remains consistently chilly all year, jumping or falling into cold water or spending longer periods than normal submerged in the water can lead to, potentially fatal, cold water shock.Water safety lead for the RNLI in Wales, Chris Cousens urged people to remember the safety advice.He said: ldquoStay in familiar surroundings and follow the Welsh Government advice.ldquoDo not put yourself, your family and emergency services at risk by taking risks or assuming it lsquowonrsquot happen to yoursquo.ldquoIf you do see someone at risk call  and ask for the coastguard.A high proportion of calls for the RNLI in Wales are to those who have been to people cut off by the tide, including during the lockdown period.Some parts of Wales have among the highest tidal range in Europe.A beach that was clear yesterday at pm might be completely covered in sea at the same time today.Mr Cousens said: ldquoIf you are heading out for a coastal walk, make sure it is safe before you go.ldquoAlways check the tide times and conditions before you set off and while out, be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on the tide direction.ldquoAsk for local advice and look out for safety signs.ldquoAlways carry a means of calling for help and know to call  and ask for the coastguardyou or someone  is at risk.The RNLI is working to start a leguard service on several beaches in Wales and is in discussion with the Welsh Government, local authorities, landowners, and other partners.At present there are no RNLI leguards on beaches in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey Sian from the MS Society Cymru said: ldquoThis really is an amazing donation and your support will allow us to continue to provide vital services for people affected by MS and to invest in groundbreaking medical research."To top off the evening of celebration the girls surprised everyone with some jaw-dropping performances by the incredible Valley Boys, a professional tribute act of west end singers dedicated to the Jersey Boys. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCHANGES to advice for people shielding from coronavirus are being introduced from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food title: contact tracing system wales rolled out
story: From today, anyone who has a positive coronavirus test result will be contacted by a team of contact tracers and asked for details of everyone they have had close contact with while they have had symptoms.Close contact means anyone who has been within m of and had a face-to-face-conversation, had skin-to-skin contact with or have coughed on, or been in other forms of contact with for a minute or longer.It also means they have been within m of for more than  minutes or they have travelled in a vehicle with or sat near on public transport.All these close contacts will be followed up and will be asked to self-isolate for  days as a precaution to prevent the virus spreading further.From Monday, June  contact tracing will be supported by a new online system, which will give people the option to provide details of their close contacts electronically.Mr Gething said: ldquoTodayrsquos roll-out of the contact tracing element of our Test, Trace, Protect strategy is a signicant step forward in the gradual move out of lockdown.ldquoOver the last few months, thanks to the help of the public and the way they have followed the stay-at-home rules, we have managed to slow the spread of the virus to the point where we can today ease the regulations to enable family and friends to meet again.ldquoContact tracing is a tried and tested method of bringing outbreaks of infectious diseases under control and we hope it will do the same with coronavirus ndash but for it to be successful, we need everyonersquos help and cooperation in sharing details about their movements and contacts."We also need people to self-isolatethey may be at risk.ldquoThe scientic advice is clear ndash we need a contact tracing system in place before we begin to lt restrictions further.Health boards and local authorities are working together to deliver contact tracing.The system has been trialled in four health board areas over the last two weeks and more than  contact tracers have so far been employed.This number is likely to rise as the system is rolled out.Testing capacity has been increased to support contact tracing and home tests and tests at the drive-through centres for both critical workers and the public can be booked online.Full details of the contact tracing system are available at gov.wales testing-coronavirus article_url   content_id   site_id title: meet environment author stephen moss penarth bookstore online event
story: Mr Moss will talk to bookshop owner Mel Grfin about his new book, The Accidental Countryside, before taking questions from the virtual audience.This online event will take place at pm on Wednesday, June  via Zoom conference call.More storiesPopular book club moves online to adapt to isolationGrfin Books nominated for Best Independent Bookshop AwardIndependent bookshop to host crime author Matt JohnsonWhat links Britainrsquos Iron Age hill forts and urban skyscrapers Churchyards and docklands Golf courses and gravel pits Together, they make up The Accidental Countryside.Wherever you go in Britain ndash in the city, town, or countryside ndash you come across hidden havens for wildle.They may be home to sand lizards and stoats, adders and orchids, water voles and peregrine falcons.In The Accidental Countryside, Mr Moss tells the fascinating and uplting story of how wildle has taken advantage of us ndash often when we least expected it.He also asks a crucial question: without these places, will Britainrsquos wildle be able to survive Mr Moss is a lelong naturalist, broadcaster and author.His books include The Twelve Birds of Christmas, Wild Kingdom: Bringing Back Britainrsquos Wildle and The Wren: A Biography. Stephen is Senior Lecturer in Nature and Travel Writing at Bath Spa University.At a time when we are all exploring our gardens and local areas like never before, this is the perfect event to help you discoverthe natural world around you.Tickets cost pound and include a discount on book purchases.For information and to book online, visit ticketsource grfinbooks article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: schools wales urged open august holidays
story: An announcement on the re-opening of schools is expected this week, having been closed to the vast majority of pupils since March , with local authorities being told that at least three weeks notice will be provided,But despite the scheduled summer holidays set to start in mid July, leaving only approximately three weeks of lessons at most,the National Education UnionCymru claims that plans for the six week break to be brought forward a month had been abandoned.More NewsDeaths in Vale of Glamorgan jump  per cent higher in AprilBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandMeet environment author Stephen Moss at Penarth bookstore online eventUnion secretaryDavid Evans, in a Facebook post, said that such a move would result in a -week term in the autumn with just a one-week break in the middle for the teachers, adding that thiswould mean breaking summer arrangements and resulting ldquocontractual issues, describing such plans as a ldquonon-starter.But Arfon MS Sian Gwenllian says thatbringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward should continue to be ldquofully explored, suggesting a phased and gradual re-opening of schools in August rather than September, but onlyit was safe to do so.Plaid Cymrursquos education spokesperson claims there could beldquoeducational advantages in bringing forward the start of the autumn term.This, she added, could further pave the way for permanent changesand a re-configuring of the traditionalthree term year in a way that would be ldquoless disjointed andmore in tune with modern-day needs.ldquoThe educational advantages of bringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward and beginning the autumn term in August should continue to be fully explored, she said.ldquoBefore the Coronavirus crisis there were on-going discussions about school term s and the need to change from three to four school terms and making the summer holidays shorter.ldquoWith need to re-visit those discussions in the wake of Coronavirus and now may be the time to consider changing school terms permanently and toreconfigurethe annual school pattern.She added that the current practice ofldquointense half terms followed by a short holiday has caused both teachers and pupils to become tired, claiming that many teacherssay that the summer term is ldquotoo long ndash especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.She concluded,ldquoAt the moment in Wales, terms are of dferent swith holidays coming irregularlyand yet research shows that continuity and progression are importantelements of learning.ldquoMany teacherssay that the summer term is too long, with the first few weeks of the autumn term being used for catch-up, especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.ldquoIn the meantime, we must crucially continue to refine remote learning. This should be central to the plans for the gradual re-opening of schools. It should also be integral to future planning too as we continue to strive to close the digital poverty ide and the attainment gap.ldquoThe focus of our education system must be on engaging with every pupil and ensuring no child is left behind.A Welsh Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Welsh Government is working closely with unions, local authorities, scientists and education staff to decide on the next steps for education in Wales and the Minister intends to update further this week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: check catch prepare summer september   wales schools enter next phase
story: Education minister Kirsty Williams MS says all schools will start the next phase on Monday, June , with the term extended by a week, therefore ending on Monday, July .In the next academic year, beginning in September, the intention is that the autumn half-term break will be expanded to two weeks.In each school there will be a phased approach.More storiesWelsh Government education minister Kirsty Williams sets out thinking on schools Welsh Government provides schools with new mental health supportSchools in Wales will remain closed on June , announces education minister Kirsty WilliamsYear groups will be split into cohorts with staggered starts, lessons, and breaks.This will mean, at most, a third of pupils present at any one time, though schools may need time to reach this level of operation.There will be much smaller classes, providing secure dedicated time with teachers and classmates.This time will include online and personalised classroom experience, getting children and teachers ready for a similar experience in September.Next week, the Welsh Government will publish guidance to support schools, as well as further and higher education institutions.This will include information on managing their facilities and logistical arrangements, including buildings, resources, cleaning and transport.The Government is also publishing a paper from its covid- Technical Advisory Group, representing the latest understanding of the virus with respect to children and education.Further Education colleges are ensuring that appropriate measures are being taken to re-open for face-to-face learning from Monday, June .They will prioritise those students requiring licence to practice assessments and vulnerable learners.This follows close working with government and the joint trade unions.Guidance for childcare providers will also be published in the next week, supporting them to increase the numbers of children in attendance alongside schools.Ms Williams said her announcement gave schools three and a half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase.She said: ldquoWe will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared ndash mentally, emotionally and practically ndash for the new normal in September.ldquo June means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand.ldquoI can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme.ldquoAs we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.ldquoThe evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.       ,params: .pushldquoWaiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling.ldquoThat would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people.ldquoThis is and has been a worrying period for us all.ldquoI know that many will feel apprehensive.ldquoWe have not rushed this work and this decision.ldquoThe three-and-a-half-week period before the next phase also gives us time to keep watch on developments where and provides further check-points to review evidence and the roll-out of testing.ldquoThis is the best practical option that meets my five principles which underpin my decision making.ldquoI am also convinced that it is only by ing to their own school that we will see increased attendance from our more vulnerable and disadvantaged children.ldquoWorking together we will secure equity and excellence for pupils as they check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: shielding continue   people wales

Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentALMOST , people will this week start receiving a letter from the chief medical Officer for Wales setting out the latest advice to protect them from coronavirus.They will be asked to continue shielding until Sunday, August , but the letter will also describe how the medical advice has changed to enable them to go outdoors to meet other people for the first time since the start of the pandemic.The shielded group are people who are classed as extremely vulnerable to developing serious illnessthey contract coronavirus because they have a specic health condition.They have been following strict shielding advice for  weeks.MORE STORIES"Check in, Catch up, Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseContact tracing system for Wales rolled-outWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWalesrsquo chief medical officer, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoSince the start of the pandemic, we have been focused on ensuring people who are at greatest risk are protected from coronavirus.ldquoThe spread of coronavirus is being carefully monitored ndashit gets lower, it is possible those within the shielded group will be able to do more.ldquoIf it gets higher, we may advise those people to stop going outside and to stay at home again.Earlier this week, the Welsh Government announced a change in advice for people who are shielding, based on a review of the evidence by the four UK chief medical officers.From June , everyone who is shielding are being advised they can leave their homes to meet people from another household outdoors, as long as strictly follow to social distancing rules and good hygiene measures. This includes exercising outdoors.The new August shielding date does not affect this updated advice.Dr Atherton said: ldquoWe are asking all those in the shielding group to continue to shield until August  because coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe want to do all we can to keep those people in this group safe and that means asking them to continue to shield.ldquoI will continue to work with my chief medical officer colleagues to review the evidence for this group and will write to them again in the summer.Everyone in the shielding group has been asked to continue to rely on their existing support networks ndash including family and friends ndashfor help with everyday tasks, such as food shopping and collecting prescription medicines.For those who do not have anyone locally, the Welsh Government has worked with local authorities and the Wales Council for Voluntary Action , major food retailers, GPs and pharmacies to ensure they can access the support they need to continue shielding.The arrangements for weekly food boxes for those people who are shielding who have no support from family or friends will continue to be in place.The Welsh Government also continues to work with supermarket retailers in Wales which offer online shopping and home delivery to make sure priority slots are available for people who are shielding.Dr Atherton added: ldquoA huge amount of work has been going on to support people who are shielding and Irsquod particularly like to thank local authorities, the WLGA, WCVA and county voluntary councils for their ongoing work and support. title: penarth church blown away response virtual sunday services
story: Members of the Tabernacle Baptist Churchhave been live streaming their brilliant virtual Sunday services via Facebook Live and Youtube, and the services have attracted hundreds of viewers, with some as far as Germany tuning in.More NewsBarry McDonalds drive thru is back in businessPupils in Wales canto school on June , Welsh Government announceBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandStarting on the second week of lockdown at the end of March, the videos have grown in popularity, and church member Jack Westmore says it is ldquosomething good to come out of a tough time.ldquoIt has been a way of bringing some familiar faces to peoplersquos homes every week, and is something for our members to look forward to, said Mr Westmore. ldquoSome are also not members and are generally interested and want to have a Sunday service.ldquoWe are very lucky that we have some brilliant musicians and tech-savvy members who have really stood up to the plate and made this lockdown bearable for so many of us.Church Elder Claire Grafton explained the impact of the virtual services, adding: ldquoWe have two elderly members who tune in, and one isnrsquot as good with the technology as the other, but one holds the screen right up to the other and they sing along. Itrsquos wonderful to see.The services have been so successful that the congregation is considering continuing its virtual services when lockdown is lted.ldquoBefore lockdown we were getting  visitors regularly on a Sunday, so I would assume that can no longer happen, so the virtual services are certainly something we are considering for the long term, said Ms Grafton.ldquoBut we canrsquot wait until we are back to the church and we are putting plans in place to ensure we can do that as soon as possible.To see Tabs Penarths videos, visit their Facebook page at https:www.facebook TabsPenarth  or their Youtube channel at https:www.youtube channel UCMwHmBLFoZkTPgNHZEw. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: world environment day wales can lead charge quest truly green recovery
story: As the world marks World Environment Day , Sir David has underlined NRWrsquos commitment to supporting the Welsh Government to deliver a green recovery that prioritises sustainable economic growth and benefits the climate and our natural environment.He also outlined how Wales must lead the way on a green route out of the covid- crisis and how Walesrsquo response to the lockdown will play a critical role in determining our effectiveness - or otherwise - in responding to the climate and nature emergencies.MORE STORIESPorthkerry Park pond project improves Barry environmentCadoxton Brook flood scheme plans will go on display at Dinas Powys Community LibraryCoastal areas expected to be hit by large wavesSir David said: ldquoThe impact of covid- has brought sharply into focus the importance we place on our local environment ndash particularly when our access to it has been limited to serve a greater purpose.ldquoIt has also made the case for tackling the climate emergency starker than ever before.The pledges NRW made last year to respond to that challenge remain at the heart of everything we do.The concept of a sustainable recovery will only add momentum to our approach to tackling the climate emergency, and deeper instil the commitment needed to succeed.Looking at how a green recovery could effectively be achieved, NRW suggests that an overall package could focus on a recovery that strengthens our local economies by capitalising on the renewed sense of place and connection we now have with our communities and developing active travel measures which will help to safeguard the quality of the air we breathe.NRW also suggests developing support packages for businesses and sectors that have decarbonisation and nature-based solutions at their core and reforming and developing longer-term policy ambitions in areas such as post-Brexit agricultural and land management support, and the approach to developing a more circular economy.Sir David also reiterated the importance of approaching the green recovery as a coalition with one voice.He added: ldquoThis World Environment Day we need everyone in Wales ndash the government, the private, third and tourism sectors, environmental NGOs, the agricultural and recreational sectors and our communities across Wales - to work together to confront this global challenge head on and seize the opportunity to lead the charge for a truly green recovery. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app crucial sorting bookings vale glamorgan recycling centre
story: First Minister Mark Drakeford announced last month that recycling centres could reopen as part of the easing of coronavirus restrictions.More than , bookings were made on the first day when they reopened in the Vale of Glamorgan ndash  bookings were made every minute.The Zipporah app called Generic, is helping people in the county to book an appointment. This is proving vital in helping recycling centres manage attendance, maintain physical distancing and reduce queuing.MORE STORIESNew app to provide specialist advice to GPs in secondsNew pound, fund to help digital firms develop technology to combat coronavirusSouth Wales freemasons donate  tablets to hospitalsResidents are also provided with clear instructions and procedures to follow before arriving and during their visit to a recycling centre.The app has also been taken up by local authorities outside Wales. Zipporah is providing it to all free of charge.Economy, Transport and North Wales Minister, Ken Skates said:ldquoThis is a fantastic example of a Welsh company taking action in a time of crisis to introduce a new product for the benefit of public services and local residents.ldquoIndications show the Generic app has already proved a success at recycling centres in the Vale of Glamorgan. This is absolutely essential in ensuring physical distancing rules are maintained and people can come and go with confidence and ease.ldquoIrsquod like to thank Zipporah and the Vale of Glamorgan Council for working collaboratively to bring a successful solution into the public domain.Zipporahrsquos technical director Scott Burton said:"Our appointment solution has already been incredibly effective especially in facilitating the organised re-opening of recycling centres ndash not only in Wales but also across England and Scotland.ldquoAs well as keeping recycling centres running smoothly, Zipporah technology has been crucial in allowing social distancing to be maintained ndash upholding the safety of both the public and staff alike.ldquoWersquore delighted with how successful the system has been in benefiting those using during this challenging period.Deputy Minister for Housing and Local Government, Hannah Blythyn said:ldquoWe have had to adapt our ways of working, since the coronavirus outbreak and it is fantastic to see local authorities and businesses coming together and using innovative technology to ensure key public services are maintained.ldquoEnsuring the safety of staff and the public at recycling centres is vital.The Generic app has not only helped to achieve this but has allowed recycling centres to run smoothly while adopting social distancing. I hope wersquoll see more of this collaborative working in the future as we respond to the pandemic.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Peter King said: ldquoWersquore delighted with how smoothly our household waste recycling centres have been able to reopen after a period of closure.ldquoAs anticipated demand for these facilities was extremely high, but thanks to proper planning and the hard work of council staff many potential problems relating to queuing and waiting times have been avoided.ldquoThe implementation of a booking system was crucial to the reopening operation and wersquod like to thank Zipporah for their support.ldquoTheyrsquove provided us with reliable and robust software that has stood up well to signicant pressure.Vale resident, Stuart Evans said: ldquoAfter a couple of months of having a full garden of shelving units, carpet, underlay, I was so grateful to be able to get to the recycling centre in Barry.ldquoTime slots worked perfectly and it felt so lsquonormalrsquo.ldquoStaff were very organised and helpful. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: wales make face masks compulsory public transport
story: Mark Drakeford said Englands decision to bring in a requirement for coverings had raised issues for people commuting between the two countries.It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for coronavirus, taking the total number of deaths to ,, while the number of positive cases grew by  to ,.More NewsLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsMans efforts toWorld War One Penarth soldiers plaque found in New ZealandPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideOn Friday, Mr Drakeford was questioned about his governments position on non-medical coverings after a trade union representing doctors in Wales said bringing in rules would help control the spread of Covid- and save lives.Mr Drakeford told the Governments daily press briefing in Cardf: "The context for face coverings has changed because of an announcement made yesterday in England about mandatory use of face masks on public transport."That will not come in until June , and that gives us a short number of days in order to consider the position here in Wales recognising that changed context."Mr Drakeford said a "definitive statement" on the issue would be made in the first part of next week, and that detailed questions about Englands new rules would be explored with ministers and officials in Westminster.But he said the UK Government had not discussed or given advanced notice of the decision with Wales, and questioned whether England was concerned with "making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards"."I wish that wed had a chance to explore this with the UK Government before they made the announcements," he said."That would have allowed us to have some answers to the questions that I raised today before the event rather than after the event."But while on the bulk of issues we continue to be able to have discussion and co-operation in advance of decision making, in a small number of cases we hear about it only after the decision has been made."He added: "Were going to have to use the time we now have to find out from them the extent to which they have got answers to these questions in advance of making the decision, or whether its a matter of making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards."Mr Drakeford said the advice from the chief medical officer for Wales remained that wearing face masks gave people "some marginal extra protection" but was not sufficient to make it mandatory."The chief medical officer has expressed his anxieties that people might do more risky things because they think a face mask offers them protection, which it doesnt," Mr Drakeford said."But context changes because in England it is mandatory to use face masks while on public transport."Trains and roads between north and south Wales weave in and out of the border all the time and in a sheer practical sense, we have to think through whether having separate regimes is a possibility when you can leave on a train that starts in Wales, goes into England, comes back into Wales, goes back into England, comes back into Wales."Earlier on Friday the British Medical AssociationWales called on the Welsh Government to change its stance on non-medical face coverings, and ensure a supply are available to the public.The trade unions council chair for Wales, Dr David Bailey, said: "BMA Cymru Wales advocates the wearing of face coverings by the public in areas where they cannot socially distance."There still remains a considerable risk of infection, and emerging evidence has shown thatmouths and noses are covered when people are in areas where they cannot socially distance, it may help in controlling the spread of infection of Covid- and therefore save lives."BMA Cymru Wales is calling on the Welsh Government to change their position immediately, to lessen the risk of the public spreading the virus."Wales main train operator, Transport for Wales, said it would "work collaboratively" with partners to ensure passengers were kept safe travelling across borders.A spokesman said: "The cross-border nature of our network means that we will continue to work collaboratively with industry partners to ensure customers understand how they can travel safely as they travel between Wales and England."The safety of our colleagues and customers is our top priority and wed like to reinforce the message to stay local and only use public transportthe journey is essential and theres no other travel alternative." article_url   content_id   site_id title: south wales detectorists discover treasure nine occasions
story: The British Museum said it was pleasing to see local museums across the country acquiring these "important archaeological objects", but urged treasure hunters to follow the laws surrounding metal detecting.More NewsNew app crucial in sorting bookings at Vale of Glamorgan recycling centreLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideIn , there were nine treasure finds reported to Central South Wales Coroners Court, which is responsible for holding treasure inquests.It means a total of  discoveries in the last three years in the area.Across England and Wales, , finds were reported last year ndash  per cent more than the year before.Lincolnshire was the best area for treasure, with  finds last year alone. In contrast, no treasure whatsoever was found in  areas.The Treasure Act, introduced in , defines treasure as discoveries older than  years.These include coins, prehistoric metallic objects and artefacts that are at least  per cent precious metal such as gold or silver.All potential treasure finds are processed by the British Museum, whose experts advise coroners on whether the find fits the definition of treasure.If a coroner rules that it is treasure, both local and national museums are given the chance to acquire the pieces, and the finder will be paid a sum depending on the treasures value.Butthe find is determined not to be treasure, or no museums want it, then it is ed to the treasure hunter.A Ministry of Justice report on last years treasure finds said the number of discoveries has been steadily increasing since the Treasure Act commenced ndash rising from just  finds in .There were  inquests concluded last year, with more than  per cent ing a verdict of treasure.Ian Richardson, treasure registrar at the British Museum, said: "The purpose of the Treasure Act is to enable important archaeological objects to be acquired by museums, for the benefit of all."It is pleasing to see local museums interested in acquiring a number of these findsthey are declared Treasure."Anyone fortunate enough to discover something they think is treasure must report their finding to the coroner within two weeks, so the court can hold an inquest to decide who should get the to keep it.Failure to do so can result in an unlimited fine or up to three months in prison.With metal detecting being permitted again as lockdown lts, Mr Richardson urged people to continue to follow the Code of Practice for Responsible Metal Detecting and report their discoveries, including Treasure. story: People marched to opposed the dam in September " Victory in campaign to save ancient woodland as dam plan is abandonedMill Stream" Skip to next photo Show caption
